words.def: Alterations and additions to the structure, rigging and equipment of a warship.[1]
words.name: A & AS

words.def: Toward the stern, relative to some object ("abaft the fore hatch").
words.name: Abaft

words.def: Further aft than the beam: a relative bearing of greater than 90 degrees from the bow: "two points abaft the beam, starboard side". That would describe "an object lying 22.5 degrees toward the rear of the ship, as measured clockwise from a perpendicular line from the right side, center, of the ship, toward the horizon."[2]
words.name: Abaft the beam

words.def: An imperative to leave the vessel immediately, usually in the face of some imminent overwhelming danger.[3] It is an order issued by the Master or a delegated person in command. (It must be a verbal order). It is usually the last resort after all other mitigating actions have failed or become impossible, and destruction or loss of the ship is imminent; and customarily followed by a command to "man the lifeboats" or life rafts.[3][4]
words.name: Abandon ship!

words.def: On the beam, a relative bearing at right angles to the centerline of the ship's keel.
words.name: Abeam

words.def: A sea shanty (song) about a young sailor trying to sleep with a maiden[5]
words.name: "Abel Brown"

words.def: Also able-bodied seaman. A merchant seaman qualified to perform all routine duties, or a junior rank in some navies.
words.name: Able seaman

words.def: On or in a vessel. Synonymous with "on board." (See also close aboard.)
words.name: Aboard

words.def: "To go about is to change the course of a ship by tacking. Ready about, or boutship, is the order to prepare for tacking."[6]
words.name: About

words.def: On or above the deck, in plain view, not hiding anything. Pirates would secret their crews below decks, thereby creating the false impression that an encounter with another ship was a casual matter of chance.[7]
words.name: Above board

words.def: The hull section of a vessel above the waterline, the visible part of a ship. Also, topsides.
words.name: Above-water hull

words.def: Special pennant flown to indicate absence of commanding officer, admiral, his chief of staff, or officer whose flag is flying (division, squadron, or flotilla commander).
words.name: Absentee pennant

words.def: The bearing of an object in relation to north. Either true bearing, using the geographical or true north, or magnetic bearing, using magnetic north. See also bearing and relative bearing.
words.name: Absolute bearing

words.def: A portable flight of steps down a ship's side.
words.name: Accommodation ladder

words.def: A ship or hulk used as housing, generally when there is a lack of quarters available ashore. An operational ship can be used, but more commonly a hulk modified for accommodation is used.
words.name: Accommodation ship (or accommodation hulk)

words.def: A letter from a state or power authorising action by a privateer. See also Letter of marque.
words.name: Act of Pardon or Act of Grace

words.def: See Battle Stations.
words.name: Action Stations

words.def: Senior naval officer of Flag rank. In ascending order of seniority, Rear Admiral, Vice Admiral, Admiral and (until about 2001 when all UK five-star ranks were discontinued) Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy). Derivation Arabic, from Amir al-Bahr ("Ruler of the sea").
words.name: Admiral

words.def: 1.  A high naval authority in charge of a state's Navy or a major territorial component. In the Royal Navy (UK) the Board of Admiralty, executing the office of the Lord High Admiral, promulgates Naval law in the form of Queen's (or King's) Regulations and Admiralty Instructions.
words.name: Admiralty

words.def: Body of law that deals with maritime cases. In the UK administered by the Probate, Divorce and Admiralty Division of the High Court of Justice or supreme court.
words.name: Admiralty law

words.def: 1.  Afloat and unattached in any way to the shore or seabed, but not under way. When referring to a vessel, it implies that the vessel is not under control and therefore goes where the wind and current take her (loose from moorings or out of place).
words.name: Adrift

words.def: A note for one month's wages issued to sailors on their signing a ship's articles.
words.name: Advance note

words.def: See aviso.
words.name: Adviso

words.def: Of a vessel which is floating freely (not aground or sunk). More generally of vessels in service ("the company has 10 ships afloat").
words.name: Afloat

words.def: 1.  In, on, or toward the front of a vessel.
words.name: Afore

words.def: 1.  The portion of the vessel behind the middle area of the vessel.
words.name: Aft

words.def: 1.  On larger ships, a secondary gangway rigged in the area aft of midship. On some military vessels, such as U.S. Naval vessels, enlisted personnel below E-7 board the ship at the afterbrow; officers and CPO/SCPO/MCPO board the ship at the brow.
words.name: Afterbrow

words.def: The 1200–1600 watch.
words.name: Afternoon watch

words.def: Resting on or touching the ground or bottom (usually involuntarily).
words.name: Aground

words.def: Forward of the bow.
words.name: Ahead

words.def: A cry to draw attention. Term used to hail a boat or a ship, as "Boat ahoy!"
words.name: Ahoy

words.def: 1.  lying broadside to the sea.
words.name: Ahull

words.def: 1.  (ATON) Any device external to a vessel or aircraft specifically intended to assist navigators in determining their position or safe course, or to warn them of dangers or obstructions to navigation.
words.name: Aid to Navigation

words.def: A warship designed with a primary mission of deploying and recovering aircraft, acting as a seagoing airbase. Since 1918, the term generally has been limited to a warship with an extensive flight deck designed to operate conventional fixed-wing aircraft. Also called a flat top or a bird farm (U.S. Navy).
words.name: Aircraft carrier

words.def: 1.  On the lee side of a ship.
words.name: Alee

words.def: Entire ship's company, both officers and enlisted personnel.
words.name: All hands

words.def: Having no night watches.
words.name: All night in

words.def: Bringing a person or thing up short, that is an unforeseen and sudden stop.[1]
words.name: All standing

words.def: A term used in maritime law - To impact a stationary object (not submerged), such as a bridge abutment or dolphin, pier or wharf, or another vessel made fast to a pier or wharf. More than incidental contact is required. The vessel is said to "allide" with the fixed object and is considered at fault. As opposed to collision.
words.name: Allision

words.def: In the rigging of a sailing ship. Above the ship's uppermost solid structure; overhead or high above.
words.name: Aloft

words.def: By the side of a ship or pier.
words.name: Alongside

words.def: The middle section of a vessel with reference to the athwartships plane, as distinguished from port or starboard ("Put your rudder amidships." (Compare Midships.))
words.name: Amidships

words.def: 1.  an object designed to prevent or slow the drift of a ship, attached to the ship by a line or chain; typically a metal, hook-like or plough-like object designed to grip the bottom under the body of water (but see also sea anchor).
words.name: Anchor

words.def: Round black shape hoisted in the forepart of a vessel to show that it is anchored.
words.name: Anchor ball

words.def: A small buoy secured by a light line to an anchor to indicate position of anchor on bottom.
words.name: Anchor buoy

words.def: Chain connecting the ship to the anchor.
words.name: Anchor chain (or anchor cable)

words.def: Group of men who handle ground tackle when the ship is anchoring or getting under way.
words.name: Anchor detail

words.def: When the anchor is secured for sea. Typically rests just outside the hawsepipe on the outer side of the hull, at the bow of a vessel.
words.name: Anchor home

words.def: White light displayed by a ship at anchor. Two such lights are displayed by a ship over 150 feet (46 m) in length.
words.name: Anchor light

words.def: The anchor line, rope or cable connecting the anchor chain to the vessel. Also Rode.
words.name: Anchor rode

words.def: A separate weight on a separate line which is loosely attached to the anchor rode so that it can slide down it easily. It is made fast at a distance slightly longer than the draft of the boat. It is used to prevent the anchor rode from becoming fouled on the keel or other underwater structures when the boat is resting at anchor and moving randomly during slack tide. Also called a kellet.
words.name: Anchor sentinel

words.def: The crewmen assigned to take care of the ship while anchored or moored, charged with such duties as making sure that the anchor is holding and the vessel is not drifting. Most marine GPS units have an Anchor Watch alarm capability.
words.name: Anchor watch

words.def: A suitable place for a ship to anchor. Area of a port or harbor.
words.name: Anchorage

words.def: Said of an anchor when just clear of the bottom.
words.name: Anchor's aweigh

words.def: Traditional lower-deck slang term for the Royal Navy.
words.name: Andrew

words.def: A pair of fluid-filled, usually water, tanks mounted on opposite sides of a ship below the waterline. Fluid would be pumped between them in an attempt to dampen the amount of roll.
words.name: Anti-rolling tanks

words.def: Over to the port side.
words.name: Aport

words.def: The combination of the true wind and the headwind caused by the boat's forward motion. For example, it causes a light side wind to appear to come from well ahead of the beam.
words.name: Apparent wind

words.def: The portion of the horizon over which a lighted aid to navigation is visible from seaward.
words.name: Arc of Visibility

words.def: The plank along the stern where the name of the ship is commonly painted.
words.name: Archboard

words.def: A ship's weapons.
words.name: Armament

words.def: Regulations governing the military and naval forces of UK and USA; read to every ship's company on commissioning and at specified intervals during the commission.
words.name: Articles of War

words.def: A direct line between two points (which might cross land) which is the way crows travel rather than ships which must go around land.
words.name: As the crow flies

words.def: Purportedly an acronym. A type of sonar used by the Allies for detecting submarines during the First and Second World War. abbreviation: Allied Submarine Devices Investigation Committee (World War I). The term has been generically applied to equipment for "under-water supersonic echo-ranging equipment" of submarines and other vessels.[9]
words.name: ASDIC

words.def: 1.  On the beach, shore, or land (as opposed to aboard or on board).
words.name: Ashore

words.def: Over to the starboard side.
words.name: Astarboard

words.def: 1.  Toward the stern (rear) of a vessel.
words.name: Astern

words.def: The gear or gears which, when engaged with an engine or motor, result in backwards movement or force. Equivalent to Reverse in a manual transmission automobile.
words.name: Astern Gear

words.def: A harbour used to provide shelter from a storm. See "Harbor of refuge."
words.name: Asylum Harbour

words.def: Anti-submarine warfare.
words.name: ASW

words.def: At right angles to the fore and aft or centerline of a ship.
words.name: Athwart, athwartships

words.def: A naval ship designed to operate in any number of roles supporting combatant ships and other naval operations, including a wide range of activities related to replenishment, transport, repair, harbor services, and research.
words.name: Auxiliary ship (or auxiliary)

words.def: Stop, cease or desist from whatever is being done. From the Dutch hou' vast ("hold on"), the imperative form of vasthouden ("to hold on to") or the Italian word "Basta"[1] Compare ¡Ya basta!
words.name: Avast

words.def: A kind of dispatch boat or advice boat, survives particularly in the French navy, they are considered equivalent to the modern sloop.
words.name: Aviso (formerly also an adviso)

words.def: So low in the water that the water is constantly washing across the surface.
words.name: Awash

words.def: Position of an anchor just clear of the bottom.
words.name: Aweigh

words.def: Fire oriented towards the ends of the ship; the opposite of broadside fire. In the age of sail this was known as 'raking' fire.
words.name: Axial fire

words.def: Reply to an order or command to indicate that it, firstly, is heard; and, secondly, is understood and will be carried out. ("Aye, aye, sir" to officers). Also the proper reply from a hailed boat, to indicate that an officer is on board.
words.name: Aye, aye /ˌaɪ ˈaɪ/

words.def: Instrument used to take bearings of celestial objects.
words.name: Azimuth circle

words.def: An instrument employed for ascertaining position of the sun with respect to magnetic north. The azimuth of an object is its bearing from the observer measured as an angle clockwise from true north.
words.name: Azimuth compass

words.def: A style of standing rigging used on sailboats that lacks a backstay. The mast is said to be supported like a "tripod," with swept-back spreaders and a forestay. Used widely on Hunter brand sailboats, among others. Designed and named by Lars Bergstrom and Sven Ridder and protected by US Patent number 3866558, dated February 18, 1975.
words.name: B & R Rig

words.def: To use the advantage of the tide being with you when the wind is not.
words.name: Back and fill

words.def: Long lines or cables, reaching from the stern of the vessel to the mast heads, used to support the mast.
words.name: Backstays

words.def: A soft covering for cables (or any other obstructions) that prevents sail chafing from occurring.
words.name: Baggywrinkle

words.def: A device for removing water that has entered the boat.
words.name: Bailer

words.def: Heavy material that is placed in the hold of a vessel to provide stability. (See also in ballast.)
words.name: Ballast

words.def: A device used on ships and submarines and other submersibles to control buoyancy and stability.
words.name: Ballast tank

words.def: The 0000–0400 watch. (US Navy)
words.name: Balls to four watch

words.def: A large area of elevated sea floor.
words.name: Bank

words.def: Traditional Royal Navy term for a day or shorter period of rest and relaxation.
words.name: Banyan

words.def: Large mass of sand or earth, formed by the surge of the sea. They are mostly found at the entrances of great rivers or havens, and often render navigation extremely dangerous, but confer tranquility once inside. See also: touch and go, grounding. Alfred Lord Tennyson's poem "Crossing the bar" is an allegory for death.
words.name: Bar

words.def: A bar pilot guides ships over the dangerous sandbars at the mouth of rivers and bays.
words.name: Bar pilot

words.def: 1.  During the second half of the 19th century, a fixed armored enclosure protecting a ship's guns aboard warships without gun turrets, generally taking the form of a ring of armor over which guns mounted on an open-topped rotating turntable could fire.
words.name: Barbette

words.def: A two- or three-masted lugger used for fishing on the coasts of Spain and Portugal and more widely in the Mediterranean Sea in the late 17th century and 18th century. The British Royal Navy also used them for shore raids and as dispatch boats in the Mediterranean.
words.name: Barca-longa

words.def: An arrangement for the chartering or hiring of a vessel, whereby the vessel's owner provides no crew or provisions as part of the agreement; instead, the people who rent the vessel are responsible for crewing and provisioning her.
words.name: Bareboat charter

words.def: 1.  A towed or self-propelled flat-bottomed boat, built mainly for river, canal, and coastal transport of heavy goods.
words.name: Barge

words.def: Alternative spelling of barque.
words.name: Bark

words.def: Alternative spelling of barquentine.
words.name: Barkentine

words.def: A sailing vessel of three or more masts, with all masts but the sternmost square-rigged, the sternmost being fore-and-aft-rigged.
words.name: Barque (also bark)

words.def: A sailing vessel with three or more masts; with a square-rigged foremast and all other masts fore-and-aft rigged.
words.name: Barquentine (also barkentine)

words.def: A ship or craft designed to function as a floating barracks for housing military personnel.
words.name: Barrack ship

words.def: A sailor that was stationed in the crow's nest.
words.name: Barrelman

words.def: 1.  A stiff strip used to support the roach of a sail, enabling increased sail area.
words.name: Batten

words.def: To prepare for inclement weather by securing the closed hatch covers with wooden battens so as to prevent water from entering from any angle.
words.name: Batten down the hatches

words.def: 1.  An announcement made aboard a naval warship to signal the crew to prepare for battle, imminent damage, or a damage emergency (such as a fire).
words.name: Battle Stations (also: general quarters, action stations)

words.def: A type of large capital ship of the first half of the 20th century, similar in size, appearance, and cost to a battleship and typically armed with the same kind of heavy guns, but much more lightly armored (on the scale of cruiser) and therefore faster than a battleship but more vulnerable to damage.
words.name: Battlecruiser

words.def: A type of large, heavily armored warship of the second half of the 19th century and first half of the 20th century armed with heavy-caliber guns, designed to fight other battleships in a line of battle. It was the successor to the ship-of-the-line of the Age of Sail.
words.name: Battleship

words.def: Deliberately running a vessel aground to load and unload (as with landing craft), or sometimes to prevent a damaged vessel sinking.
words.name: Beaching

words.def: A lighted or unlighted fixed aid to navigation attached directly to the earth's surface. (Lights and daybeacons both constitute beacons.)
words.name: Beacon

words.def: 1.  The ram on the prow of a fighting galley of ancient and medieval times.
words.name: Beakhead

words.def: The width of a vessel at the widest point, or a point alongside the ship at the midpoint of its length.
words.name: Beam

words.def: The sides of a ship. "On her beam ends" may mean the vessel is literally on her side and possibly about to capsize; more often, the phrase means the vessel is listing 45 degrees or more.
words.name: Beam ends

words.def: Sailing with the wind coming across the vessel's beam. This is normally the fastest point of sail for a fore-and-aft rigged vessel.
words.name: Beam reach

words.def: A sea where waves are moving perpendicular to the direction a ship is moving
words.name: Beam sea

words.def: A wind at right angles to the vessel's course.
words.name: Beam wind

words.def: Large squared off stone used with sand for scraping clean wooden decks.
words.name: Bear

words.def: To steer (a vessel) away from the wind.
words.name: Bear away

words.def: Turn away from the wind, often with reference to a transit.
words.name: Bear down or bear away

words.def: The horizontal direction of a line of sight between two objects on the surface of the earth. See also absolute bearing and relative bearing.
words.name: Bearing

words.def: Prepare for battle (beat = beat the drum to signal the need for battle preparation)
words.name: Beat to quarters

words.def: Sailing as close as possible towards the wind (perhaps only about 60°) in a zig-zag course to attain an upwind direction to which it is impossible to sail directly.(also tacking)
words.name: Beating or Beat to

words.def: The scale describing wind force devised by Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort in 1808, in which winds are graded by the effect of their force (originally, the amount of sail that a fully rigged frigate could carry).
words.name: Beaufort scale

words.def: To cut off the wind from a sailing vessel, either by the proximity of land or by another vessel.
words.name: Becalm

words.def: Unable to move due to lack of wind; said of a sailing vessel.
words.name: Becalmed

words.def: Literally, the area of a ship before the foremast (the forecastle). Most often used to refer to men whose living quarters are located here, officers being quartered in the stern-most areas of the ship (near the quarterdeck). Officer-trainees lived between the two ends of the ship and become known as "midshipmen". Crew members who started out as seamen, then became midshipmen, and later, officers, were said to have gone from "one end of the ship to the other" (See also hawsepiper.)
words.name: Before the mast

words.def: 1.  To make fast a line around a fitting, usually a cleat or belaying pin.
words.name: Belay

words.def: Short movable bars of iron or hard wood to which running rigging may be secured, or belayed.
words.name: Belaying pins

words.def: A type of buoy with a large bell and hanging hammers that sound by wave action.[citation needed] (See also ship's bell.)
words.name: Bell

words.def: On or into a lower deck, e.g., The captain has gone below.
words.name: Below

words.def: In or into any of the spaces below the main deck of a vessel.
words.name: Below decks

words.def: A layer of heavy metal armor plated onto or within the outer hulls of warships, typically on battleships, battlecruisers, cruisers, and aircraft carriers, usually covering the warship from her main deck down to some distance below the waterline. If built within the hull, rather than forming the outer hull, the belt would be installed at an inclined angle to improve the warship's protection from shells striking the hull.
words.name: Belt armor

words.def: A knot used to join two ropes or lines. See also hitch.
words.name: Bend

words.def: A triangular mainsail, without any upper spar, which is hoisted up the mast by a single halyard attached to the head of the sail. This configuration, introduced to Europe about 1920, allows the use of a tall mast, enabling sails to be set higher where wind speed is greater.
words.name: Bermuda rig or Bermudan rig

words.def: A fore-and-aft rigged sailing vessel with Bermuda rig developed in Bermuda in the 17th century. In its purest form, it is single-masted, although Bermuda sloops can have up to three masts, three-masted ships being referred to as schooners. Originally gaff rigged, but evolved to use Bermuda rig. The Bermuda sloop is the basis of nearly all modern sailing yachts.
words.name: Bermuda sloop

words.def: A location in a port or harbour used specifically for mooring vessels while not at sea.
words.name: Berth (moorings)

words.def: Safety margin of distance to be kept by a vessel from another vessel or from an obstruction, hence the phrase, "to give a wide berth."[10]
words.name: Berth (navigation)

words.def: A bed or sleeping accommodation on a boat or ship.
words.name: Berth (sleeping)

words.def: The larger of two anchors carried in the bow; so named as it was the last, best hope.
words.name: Best bower (anchor)

words.def: See devil seam.
words.name: Between the devil and the deep blue sea

words.def: The part of a ship's hull that is sometimes submerged and sometimes brought above water by the rolling of the vessel.
words.name: Between wind and water

words.def: 1.  Bight, a loop in rope or line—a hitch or knot tied on the bight is one tied in the middle of a rope, without access to the ends.
words.name: Bight /ˈbaɪt/

words.def: a small European merchant sailing ship with two masts, the mainmast lateen-rigged with a trapezoidal mainsail, and the foremast carrying the conventional square course and square topsail. Used in the Netherlands for coast and canal traffic and occasionally in the North Sea, but more frequently used in the Mediterranean Sea.
words.name: Bilander (also billander or be'landre)

words.def: The compartment at the bottom of the hull of a ship or boat where water collects and must be pumped out of the vessel.
words.name: Bilge

words.def: A pair of keels on either side of the hull, usually slanted outwards. In yachts, they allow the use of a drying mooring, the boat standing upright on the keels (and often a skeg) when the tide is out.
words.name: Bilge keels

words.def: A ship that has run upon her own anchor, so the anchor cable runs under the hull.
words.name: Bilged on her anchor

words.def: The extremity of the arm of an anchor; the point of or beyond the fluke.
words.name: Bill

words.def: Open-front canvas top for the cockpit of a boat, usually supported by a metal frame.
words.name: Bimini top

words.def: A punitive instrument
words.name: Bimmy

words.def: The stand on which the ship's compass is mounted.
words.name: Binnacle

words.def: A ship's sick list. The list of men unable to report for duty was given to the officer or mate of the watch by the ship's surgeon. The list was kept at the binnacle.
words.name: Binnacle list

words.def: Verb used in reference to a rudder, as in "the rudder begins to bite." When a vessel has steerageway the rudder will act to steer the vessel, i.e. it has enough water flow past it to steer with. Physically this is noticeable with tiller or unassisted wheel steering by the rudder exhibiting resistance to being turned from the straight ahead - this resistance is the rudder "biting" and is how a helmsman first senses that the vessel has acquired steerageway.
words.name: Bite

words.def: A post or pair mounted on the ship's bow, for fastening ropes or cables.
words.name: Bitt or bitts

words.def: The last part or loose end of a rope or cable. The anchor cable is tied to the bitts; when the cable is fully paid out, the bitter end has been reached.
words.name: Bitter end

words.def: The engineering crew of the vessel, i.e., crewmembers who work in the vessel's engine room, fire room, and boiler room, so called because they would be covered in coal dust during the days of coal-fired steamships.
words.name: Black gang

words.def: A pulley or set of pulleys.
words.name: Block

words.def: A blue and white flag (the flag for the letter "P") hoisted at the foretrucks of ships about to sail. Formerly a white ship on a blue ground, but later a white square on a blue ground.
words.name: Blue Peter

words.def: 1.  To step onto, climb onto, or otherwise enter a vessel.
words.name: Board

words.def: 1.  A small craft or vessel designed to float on, and provide transport over, or under, water.
words.name: Boat

words.def: A pole with a hook on the end, used to reach into the water to catch buoys or other floating objects.
words.name: Boat-hook

words.def: A non-commissioned officer responsible for the sails, ropes, rigging and boats on a ship who issues "piped" commands to seamen.
words.name: Boatswain or bosun (both /ˈboʊsən/)

words.def: A high-pitched pipe or a non-diaphragm-type whistle used on naval ships by a boatswain, historically to pass commands to the crew but in modern times limited to ceremonial use.
words.name: Boatswain's call, also bosun's call, boatswain's pipe, bosun's pipe, boatswain's whistle, or bosun's whistle

words.def: A short board or swatch of heavy canvas, secured in a bridle of ropes, used to hoist a man aloft or over the ship's side for painting and similar work. Modern boatswain's chairs incorporate safety harnesses to prevent the occupant from falling.
words.name: Boatswain's chair or bosun's chair

words.def: See boatswain's call.
words.name: Boatswain's pipe

words.def: See boatswain's call.
words.name: Boatswain's whistle

words.def: A maker of boats, especially of traditional wooden construction.
words.name: Boatwright

words.def: A stay which holds the bowsprit downwards, counteracting the effect of the forestay. Usually made of wire or chain to eliminate stretch.
words.name: Bobstay

words.def: In shipbuilding, an end elevation showing the contour of the sides of a ship at certain points of her length.
words.name: Body plan

words.def: See fire room.
words.name: Boiler room

words.def: A rope, sewn on to reinforce the edges of a sail.
words.name: Bolt rope

words.def: From "bol" or "bole", the round trunk of a tree. A substantial vertical pillar to which lines may be made fast. Generally on the quayside rather than the ship.
words.name: Bollard

words.def: Large cockroach.
words.name: Bombay runner

words.def: A type of tobacco or sweet cake.
words.name: Bonded jacky

words.def: A strip of canvas secured to the foot of the course (square sail) to increase sail area in light airs.
words.name: Bonnet

words.def: A type of bird that has little fear and therefore is particularly easy to catch.
words.name: Booby

words.def: A sliding hatch or cover.
words.name: Booby hatch

words.def: A floating barrier to control navigation into and out of rivers and harbours.
words.name: Boom (navigational barrier)

words.def: A spar attached to the foot of a fore-and-aft sail.
words.name: Boom (sailing)

words.def: Slang term in the U.S. Navy for a ballistic missile submarine.
words.name: Boomer

words.def: A raised crossmember that supports a boom when the sail is lowered (obviates the need for a topping lift).
words.name: Boom gallows

words.def: A sail control that lets one apply downward tension on a boom, countering the upward tension provided by the sail. The boom vang adds an element of control to sail shape when the sheet is let out enough that it no longer pulls the boom down. Boom vang tension helps control leech twist, a primary component of sail power.
words.name: Boom vang or vang

words.def: See bumpkin.
words.name: Boomkin

words.def: Masts or yards, lying on board in reserve.
words.name: Booms

words.def: To assume a position to engage, or disengage, the enemy ship(s)
words.name: Bore, as in Bore up or Bore away

words.def: See boatswain.
words.name: Bosun

words.def: See boatswain's call.
words.name: Bosun's call

words.def: See boatswain's chair.
words.name: Bosun's chair

words.def: See boatswain's call.
words.name: Bosun's pipe

words.def: See boatswain's call.
words.name: Bosun's whistle

words.def: A device for adjusting tension in stays, shrouds and similar lines.
words.name: Bottlescrew

words.def: 1.  The underside of a vessel; the portion of a vessel that is always underwater; .
words.name: Bottom

words.def: Pledging a ship as security in a financial transaction.
words.name: Bottomry

words.def: 1.  The front of a vessel.
words.name: Bow

words.def: See chase gun
words.name: Bow chaser

words.def: A small propeller or water-jet at the bow, used for manoeuvring larger vessels at slow speed. May be mounted externally, or in a tunnel running through the bow from side to side.
words.name: Bow thruster

words.def: A type of knot, producing a strong loop of a fixed size, topologically similar to a sheet bend. Also a rope attached to the side of a sail to pull it towards the bow (for keeping the windward edge of the sail steady).
words.name: Bowline

words.def: To pull or hoist.
words.name: Bowse

words.def: A spar projecting from the bow used as an anchor for the forestay and other rigging.
words.name: Bowsprit

words.def: To state all 32 points of the compass, starting at north, proceeding clockwise. Sometimes applied to a wind that is constantly shifting.
words.name: Boxing the compass

words.def: a young sailor, still in training
words.name: Boy Seaman

words.def: To bring the foreyards flat aback to stop the ship.
words.name: Brace abox

words.def: To furl or truss a sail by pulling it in towards the mast, or the ropes used to do so.
words.name: Brail

words.def: The handle of the pump, by which it is worked.
words.name: Brake

words.def: Used in the expression "it is cold enough to freeze the balls off a brass monkey."
words.name: Brass monkey or brass monkey weather

words.def: Early 20th-century slang term for a vessel's radio operator, so called because he repeatedly struck a brass key on his transmitter to broadcast in Morse code.
words.name: Brass pounder

words.def: Goods that must be loaded aboard a ship individually, and not in intermodal containers or in bulk, carried by a general cargo ship.
words.name: Break bulk cargo (or breakbulk cargo)

words.def: 1.  A structure constructed on a coast as part of a coastal defense system or to protect an anchorage from the effects of weather and longshore drift.
words.name: Breakwater

words.def: A ring lifebuoy fitted with canvas breeches, functionally similar to a zip line, used to transfer people from one ship to another or to rescue people from a wrecked or sinking ship by moving them to another ship or to the shore.
words.name: Breeches buoy

words.def: A structure above the weather deck, extending the full width of the vessel, which houses a command centre, itself called by association, the bridge.
words.name: Bridge

words.def: An open-air extension of the bridge to port or starboard, intended for use in signaling.
words.name: Bridge wing

words.def: 1.  (historically) A vessel with two square-rigged masts.
words.name: Brig

words.def: A type of sloop-of-war introduced in the 1770s which had two square-rigged masts like a brig (in contrast to ship sloops of the time, which had three masts).
words.name: Brig sloop

words.def: A two-masted vessel, square-rigged on the foremast, but fore-and-aft-rigged on the mainmast.
words.name: Brigantine (also hermaphrodite brig)

words.def: Exposed varnished wood or polished metal on a boat.
words.name: Brightwork

words.def: Cause a ship to be stationary by arranging the sails.
words.name: Bring to

words.def: When a sailing vessel loses control of its motion and is forced into a sudden sharp turn, often heeling heavily and in smaller vessels sometimes leading to a capsize. The change in direction is called broaching-to. Occurs when too much sail is set for a strong gust of wind, or in circumstances where the sails are unstable.
words.name: Broach

words.def: Wide (broad) in appearance from the vantage point of a lookout or other person viewing activity in the vicinity of a ship, e.g., another ship off the starboard bow with her side facing the viewer's ship could be described as "broad on the starboard bow" of the viewer's ship.
words.name: Broad

words.def: 1.  One side of a vessel above the waterline.
words.name: Broadside

words.def: See gangplank.
words.name: Brow

words.def: The chief bosun's mate (in the Royal Navy), responsible for discipline.
words.name: Buffer

words.def: A protruding bulb at the bow of a ship just below the waterline which modifies the way water flows around the hull, reducing drag and thus increasing speed, range, fuel efficiency, and stability.
words.name: Bulbous bow

words.def: Commodity cargo that is transported unpackaged in large quantities.
words.name: Bulk cargo

words.def: A merchant ship specially designed to transport unpackaged bulk cargo in its cargo holds.
words.name: Bulk carrier (also bulk freighter or bulker)

words.def: An upright wall within the hull of a ship. Particularly a watertight, load-bearing wall.
words.name: Bulkhead

words.def:
Bulwark (or Bulward)


The extension of the ship's side above the level of the weather deck.
words.name: Bulwark or Bulward (/ˈbʊlək/ in nautical use)

words.def: The senior ensign (q.v.) of a United States Navy command (i.e., a ship, squadron, or shore activity). The bull ensign assumes additional responsibilities beyond those of other ensigns, such as teaching less-experienced ensigns about life at sea, planning and coordinating wardroom social activities, making sure that the officers' mess runs smoothly, and serving as an officer for Navy-related social organizations. The bull ensign also serves as the focal point for the unit's expression of spirit and pride.
words.name: Bull ensign (also "boot ensign" or "George ensign")

words.def: A private boat selling goods.
words.name: Bumboat

words.def: 1.  A spar, similar to a bowsprit, but which projects from the stern. May be used to attach the backstay or mizzen sheets.
words.name: Bumpkin or boomkin

words.def: A container for storing coal or fuel oil for a ship's engine.
words.name: Bunker

words.def: Fuel oil for a ship.
words.name: Bunker fuel or bunkers

words.def: A signalman who prepares and flies flag hoists. Also known in the American Navy as a skivvy waver.
words.name: Bunting tosser

words.def: One of the lines tied to the bottom of a square sail and used to haul it up to the yard when furling.
words.name: Buntline

words.def: A floating object of defined shape and color, which is anchored at a given position and serves as an aid to navigation.
words.name: Buoy

words.def: Lifted by a buoy, especially a cable that has been lifted to prevent it from trailing on the bottom.
words.name: Buoyed up

words.def: The Builder's Old Measurement, expressed in "tons bm" or "tons BOM", a volumetric measurement of cubic cargo capacity, not of weight. This is the tonnage of a ship, based on the number of tuns of wine that it could carry in its holds. One 252-gallon tun of wine takes up approximately 100 cubic feet – and, incidentally, weighs 2,240 lbs (1 long ton, or Imperial ton).
words.name: Burden (Early Modern English: Burthen, Middle English: Byrthen)

words.def: A small flag, typically triangular, flown from the masthead of a yacht to indicate yacht-club membership.
words.name: Burgee

words.def: By means into the wind, while large means with the wind. "By and large" is used to indicate all possible situations "the ship handles well both by and large".
words.name: By and large

words.def: Anything that has gone overboard.
words.name: By the board

words.def: an enclosed room on a deck or flat.
words.name: Cabin

words.def: attendant on passengers and crew. often a young man
words.name: Cabin boy

words.def: A large rope.
words.name: Cable

words.def: A measure of length or distance. Equivalent to (UK) 1/10 nautical mile, approx. 600 feet; (USA) 120 fathoms, 720 feet (219 m); other countries use different values.
words.name: Cable length

words.def: a small ship's kitchen, or galley on deck.
words.name: Caboose

words.def: The transport of goods or passengers between two points in the same country, alongside coastal waters, by a vessel or an aircraft registered in another country.
words.name: Cabotage

words.def: Loaded vessels lashed tightly, one on each side of another vessel, and then emptied to provide additional buoyancy that reduces the draught of the ship in the middle.
words.name: Camels

words.def: 1.  A type of navigational buoy often a vertical drum, but if not, always square in silhouette, colored red in IALA region A or green in IALA region B (the Americas, Japan, Korea and the Philippines). In channel marking its use is opposite that of a "nun buoy".
words.name: Can

words.def: A specialized watercraft designed for operation on a canal.
words.name: Canal boat

words.def: a type of antipersonnel cannon load in which lead balls or other loose metallic items were enclosed in a tin or iron shell. On firing, the shell would disintegrate, releasing the smaller metal objects with a shotgun-like effect.
words.name: Canister

words.def: A design for the stern of a yacht which is pointed, like a bow, rather than squared off as a transom.
words.name: Canoe stern

words.def: The name of the fake illness a malingerer is pretending to suffer from.
words.name: Cape Horn fever

words.def: A navy's most important warships, generally possessing the heaviest firepower and armor and traditionally much larger than other naval vessels, but not formally defined. During the Age of Sail, generally understood to be ships-of-the-line; during the second half of the 19th century and the 20th century, understood to be battleships and battlecruisers; and since the 1940s considered to include aircraft carriers. Since the second half of the 20th century, ballistic missile submarines sometimes have been considered capital ships.
words.name: Capital ship

words.def: When a ship or boat lists too far and rolls over, exposing the keel. On large vessels, this often results in the sinking of the ship. Compare Turtling, infra.
words.name: Capsize

words.def: A large winch with a vertical axis. A full-sized human-powered capstan is a waist-high cylindrical machine, operated by a number of hands who each insert a horizontal capstan bar in holes in the capstan and walk in a circle. Used to wind in anchors or other heavy objects; and sometimes to administer flogging over.
words.name: Capstan

words.def: 1.  The person lawfully in command of a vessel. "Captain" is an informal title of respect given to the commander of a naval vessel regardless of his or her formal rank; aboard a merchant ship, the ship's master is her "captain."
words.name: Captain

words.def: 1.  In the United Kingdom, a Royal Navy officer, usually a captain, responsible for the day-to-day operation of a naval dockyard.
words.name: Captain of the Port

words.def: The cat o' nine tails, which in principle is only used on board on the captain's (or a court martial's) personal orders.
words.name: Captain's daughter

words.def: An unpowered barge with railroad tracks mounted on its deck, used to move railroad cars across water obstacles.
words.name: Car float (also railroad car float or rail barge)

words.def: A small, highly maneuverable sailing ship with lateen rig used by the Portuguese in the 15th and 16th centuries to explore along the West African coast and into the Atlantic Ocean.
words.name: Caravel (also caravelle)

words.def: Referring to the four main points of the compass: north, south, east and west. See also bearing.
words.name: Cardinal

words.def: Tilting a ship on its side, usually when beached, to clean or repair the hull below the water line. Also known as to "heave down".
words.name: Careening

words.def: Any sort of ship or vessel that carries cargo, goods, and materials from one port to another, including general cargo ships (designed to carry break bulk cargo), bulk carriers, container ships, multipurpose vessels, and tankers. Tankers, however, although technically cargo ships, are routinely thought of as constituting a completely separate category.
words.name: Cargo ship

words.def: 1.  In the Age of Sail, a warrant officer responsible for the hull, masts, spars, and boats of a vessel, and whose responsibility was to sound the well to see if the vessel was making water.
words.name: Carpenter

words.def: A three- or four-masted sailing ship used by Western Europeans in the Atlantic Ocean from the 15th through the early 17th century.
words.name: Carrack (also nau)

words.def: A short, smoothbore, cast iron naval cannon, used from the 1770s to the 1850s as a powerful, short-range anti-ship and anti-crew weapon.
words.name: Carronade

words.def: A method of constructing wooden hulls by fixing planks to a frame so that the planks butt up against each other. Cf. "clinker built".
words.name: Carvel built

words.def: 1.  To prepare an anchor, after raising it by lifting it with a tackle to the cat head, prior to securing (fishing) it alongside for sea. (An anchor raised to the cat head is said to be catted.)
words.name: Cat

words.def: A short nine-tailed whip kept by the bosun's mate to flog sailors (and soldiers in the Army). When not in use, the cat was kept in a baize bag, this is a possible origin for the term "cat out of the bag," though livestock trade was more likely[11] where this phrase came from. "Not enough room to swing a cat" also derives from this.
words.name: Cat o' nine tails

words.def: A vessel with two hulls.
words.name: Catamaran

words.def: A cat-rigged vessel with a single mast mounted close to the bow, and only one sail, usually on a gaff.
words.name: Catboat

words.def: A short rope or iron clamp used to brace in the shrouds toward the masts so as to give a freer sweep to the yards.
words.name: Catharpin

words.def: A beam extending out from the hull used to support an anchor when raised in order to secure or 'fish' it.
words.name: Cathead

words.def: Light variable winds on calm waters producing scattered areas of small waves.
words.name: Cats paws

words.def: A lining applied to the interior of a hull for both aesthetic reasons and to bar or insulate the ship's cargo from the cold hull surface. Often made of thin strips of wood, attached horizontally with a small gap between to allow air flow to the interior hull surface.
words.name: Ceiling

words.def: The point of origin of net aerodynamic force on sails, roughly located in the geometric center of a sail, but the actual position of the center of effort will vary with sail plan, sail trim or airfoil profile, boat trim, and point of sail. Also known as center (or centre) of pressure
words.name: Center of effort (or centre of effort)

words.def: The point of origin of net hydrodynamic resistance on the submerged structure of a boat, especially a sailboat. This is the pivot point about which the boat turns when unbalanced external forces are applied, similar to the center of gravity. On a balanced sailboat the center of effort should align vertically with the center of lateral resistance. If this is not the case the boat will be unbalanced and exhibit either lee helm or weather helm and will be difficult to control.
words.name: Center of lateral resistance (or centre of lateral resistance)

words.def: An imaginary line down the center of a vessel lengthwise. Any structure or anything mounted or carried on a vessel that straddles this line and is equidistant from either side of the vessel is on the centerline (or centreline).
words.name: Centerline (or centerline)

words.def: A board or plate lowered through the hull of a dinghy on the centreline to resist leeway.
words.name: Centreboard (or centerboard)

words.def: Wear on line or sail caused by constant rubbing against another surface.
words.name: Chafing

words.def: Material applied to a line or spar to prevent or reduce chafing. See Baggywrinkle.
words.name: Chafing gear

words.def: A space in the forward part of the ship, typically beneath the bow in front of the foremost collision bulkhead, that contains the anchor chain when the anchor is secured for sea.
words.name: Chain locker

words.def: Cannon balls linked with chain used to damage rigging and masts.
words.name: Chain-shot

words.def: A broad, thick plank that projects horizontally from each of a ship's sides abreast a mast, distinguished as the fore, main, or mizzen channel accordingly, serving to extend the base for the shrouds, which supports the mast.
words.name: Chain-wale or channel

words.def: Small platforms built into the sides of a ship to spread the shrouds to a more advantageous angle. Also used as a platform for manual depth sounding.
words.name: Chains

words.def: The metal stovepipe chimney from a cook shack on the deck of a ship or from a stove in a galley .
words.name: Charley Noble

words.def: A compartment, especially in the Royal Navy, from which the ship was navigated.
words.name: Charthouse

words.def: A cannon pointing forward or aft, often of longer range than other guns. Those on the bow (bow chaser) were used to fire upon a ship ahead, while those on the rear (stern chaser) were used to ward off pursuing vessels. Unlike guns pointing to the side, chasers could be brought to bear in a chase without slowing.
words.name: Chase gun, chase piece, or chaser

words.def: 1.  Wooden blocks at the side of a spar.
words.name: Cheeks

words.def: 1.  An angle in the hull.
words.name: Chine

words.def: Hole or ring attached to the hull to guide a line via that point. An opening in a ships bulwark normally oval in shape designed to allow mooring lines to be fastened to cleats or bits mounted to the ship's deck. See also Panama chock and Dutchman's chock.
words.name: Chock

words.def: Rigging blocks that are so tight against one another that they cannot be further tightened.
words.name: Chock-a-block

words.def: A timekeeper accurate enough to be used to determine longitude by means of celestial navigation.
words.name: Chronometer

words.def: see go-fast boat.
words.name: Cigarette boat

words.def: A fortified safe room on a vessel to take shelter in the event of pirate attack. Previously, a fortified room to protect ammunition and machinery from damage.
words.name: Citadel

words.def: The British Naval Ensign or Flag of the British Merchant Navy, a red flag with the Union Flag in the upper left corner. Colloquially called the "red duster".
words.name: Civil Red Ensign

words.def: 1.  A group of naval ships of the same or similar design.
words.name: Class

words.def: A certificate issued by a port indicating that the ship carries no infectious diseases. Also called a pratique.
words.name: Clean bill of health

words.def: At the helm, the watch keeper would record details of speed, distances, headings, etc. on a slate. At the beginning of a new watch the slate would be wiped clean.
words.name: Clean slate

words.def: To perform customs and immigration legalities prior to leaving port.
words.name: Clear

words.def: A stationary device used to secure a rope aboard a vessel.
words.name: Cleat

words.def: A method of fixing together two pieces of wood, usually overlapping planks, by driving a nail through both planks as well as a washer-like rove. The nail is then burred or riveted over to complete the fastening.
words.name: Clench

words.def: The lower corners of square sails or the corner of a triangular sail at the end of the boom.
words.name: Clew

words.def: Used to truss up the clews, the lower corners of square sails.
words.name: Clew-lines

words.def: A method of constructing hulls that involves overlapping planks, and/or plates, much like Viking longships, resulting in speed and flexibility in small boat hulls. Cf. "carvel built".
words.name: Clinker built

words.def: A very fast sailing ship of the 19th century that had three or more masts, a square rig, a long, low hull, and a sharply raked stem.
words.name: Clipper

words.def: Near a ship.
words.name: Close aboard

words.def: Of a vessel beating as close to the wind direction as possible.
words.name: Close-hauled

words.def: The ship drops one of its anchors at high speed to turn abruptly. This was sometimes used as a means to get a good firing angle on a pursuing vessel. See kedge.
words.name: Club hauling

words.def: A hulk used to store coal.
words.name: Coal hulk

words.def: person responsible for ensuring that a coal-fired vessel remains in 'trim' (evenly balanced) as coal is consumed on a voyage.
words.name: Coal trimmer, or Trimmer

words.def: The raised edge of a hatch, cockpit or skylight to help keep out water.
words.name: Coaming

words.def: A shallow-hulled ship used for trade between locations on the same island or continent.
words.name: Coaster (or coastal trading vessel)

words.def: The seating area (not to be confused with Deck). The area towards the stern of a small decked vessel that houses the rudder controls.
words.name: Cockpit

words.def: A type of sailing ship with a single mast and square-rigged single sail first developed in the 10th century and widely used, particularly in the Baltic Sea region, in seagoing trade from the 12th through the 14th century.
words.name: Cog

words.def: A bulk cargo ship designed to carry coal, especially such a ship in naval use to supply coal to coal-fired warships.
words.name: Collier

words.def: A long, curving wave breaking on the shore.
words.name: Comber

words.def: 1.  To tack.
words.name: Come about

words.def: To stop a sailing vessel, especially by turning into the wind.
words.name: Come to

words.def: To formally place (a naval vessel) into active service, after which the vessel is said to be in commission. Sometimes used less formally to mean placing a commercial ship into service.
words.name: Commission

words.def: 1.  Commodore (rank), a military rank used in many navies that is superior to a navy captain, but below a rear admiral. Often equivalent to the rank of "flotilla admiral" or sometimes "counter admiral" in non-English-speaking navies.
words.name: Commodore

words.def: An air-filled tube, usually armored, allowing speech between the conning tower with the below-decks control spaces in a warship.
words.name: Communication tube, speaking tube, or voice tube

words.def: A raised and windowed hatchway in the ship's deck, with a ladder leading below and the hooded entrance-hatch to the main cabins.
words.name: Companionway

words.def: Navigational instrument showing the direction of the vessel in relation to the Earth's geographical poles or magnetic poles. Commonly consists of a magnet aligned with the Earth's magnetic field, but other technologies have also been developed, such as the gyrocompass.
words.name: Compass

words.def: The number of persons in a ship's crew, including officers.
words.name: Complement

words.def: To include or contain: As applied to a naval task force, the listing of all assigned units for a single transient purpose (mission). "The Task Force comprises Ship A, Ship B, and Ship C." 'Comprise' means exhaustive inclusion – there aren't any other parts to the task force, and each ship has a permanent squadron existence, independent of the task force.
words.name: Comprise

words.def: (Also written con, conne, conde, cunde, or cun) To direct a ship or submarine from a position of command. While performing this duty, an officer is said to have the conn.
words.name: Conn

words.def: An officer on a naval vessel responsible for instructing the helmsman on the course to steer. While performing this duty, the officer is said to have the conn.
words.name: Conning officer

words.def: 1.  The armoured control tower of an iron or steel warship built between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries from which the ship was navigated in battle.
words.name: Conning tower

words.def: Unpowered Great Lakes vessels, usually a fully loaded schooner, barge, or steamer barge, towed by a larger steamer that would often tow more than one barge. The consort system was used in the Great Lakes from the 1860s to around 1920.
words.name: Consort

words.def: When two boats are approaching each other from any angle and this angle remains the same over time (constant bearing) they are on a collision course. Because of the implication of disaster (ships might collide) it has come to mean a problem or an obstacle which is heading your way. Often used in the sense of a warning, as in "watch out for this problem you might not see coming."[12]
words.name: Constant bearing, decreasing range (CBDR)

words.def: A cargo ship that carries all of her cargo in truck-size intermodal containers.
words.name: Container ship

words.def: A group of ships traveling together for mutual support and protection.
words.name: Convoy

words.def: An amateur yachter.[13][14]
words.name: Corinthian

words.def: A device to correct the ship's compass, for example counteracting errors due to the magnetic effects of a steel hull.
words.name: Corrector

words.def: 1.  A French privateer, especially from the port of St-Malo.
words.name: Corsair

words.def: 1.  A flush-decked sailing warship of the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries having a single tier of guns, ranked next below a frigate. Called in the United States Navy a sloop-of-war.
words.name: Corvette

words.def: The part of the stern above the waterline that extends beyond the rudder stock culminating in a small transom. A long counter increases the waterline length when the boat is heeled, so increasing hull speed.
words.name: Counter

words.def: To deliberately flood compartments on the opposite side from already flooded ones. Usually done to reduce a list.
words.name: Counterflood

words.def: The direction in which a vessel is being steered, usually given in degrees.
words.name: Course

words.def: the lowest square sail on each mast — The mainsail, foresail, and the mizzen on a four masted ship (the after most mast usually sets a gaff driver or spanker instead of a square sail).
words.name: Courses

words.def: 1.  A ship's ventilator with a bell-shaped top which can be swivelled to catch the wind and force it below.
words.name: Cowl

words.def: The helmsman or crew member in command of a boat.
words.name: Coxswain or cockswain /ˈkɒksən/

words.def: A fitting, mounted at the end of a bowsprit to which stays are attached.
words.name: Crance/Crans/Cranze iron

words.def: A ship with a crane specialized in lifting heavy loads.
words.name: Crane vessel or crane ship

words.def: United States Navy slang for a maneuver in which a submerged Soviet or Russian submarine suddenly turns 180 degrees or through 360 degrees to detect submarines following it.
words.name: Crazy Ivan

words.def: 1.  On warships and merchant ships, those members of a ship's company who are not officers
words.name: Crew

words.def: A rope loop, usually at the corners of a sail, for fixing the sail to a spar. They are often reinforced with a metal eye.
words.name: Cringle

words.def: a square yard used to spread the foot of a topsail where no course is set, e.g. on the foremast of a topsail schooner or above the driver on the mizzen mast of a ship rigged vessel.
words.name: Cro'jack or crossjack

words.def: two horizontal struts at the upper ends of the topmasts of sailboats, used to anchor the shrouds from the topgallant mast.
words.name: Crosstrees

words.def: see as the crow flies.
words.name: Crow flies, as the

words.def: Specifically a masthead constructed with sides and sometimes a roof to shelter the lookouts from the weather, generally by whaling vessels, this has become a generic term for what is properly called masthead. See masthead.
words.name: Crow's nest

words.def: A passenger ship used for pleasure voyages, where the voyage itself and the ship's amenities are part of the experience, as well as the different destinations along the way. Transportation is not the prime purpose, as cruise ships operate mostly on routes that return passengers to their originating port. A cruise ship contrasts with a passenger liner, which is a passenger ship that provides a scheduled service between published ports primarily as a mode of transportation. Large, prestigious passenger ships used for either purpose sometimes are called ocean liners.
words.name: Cruise ship

words.def: 1.  From the mid-19th century to the mid-20th century, a classification for a wide variety of gun- and sometimes torpedo-armed warships, usually but not always armored, intended for independent scouting, raiding, or commerce protection; some were designed also to provide direct support to a battlefleet. Cruisers carried out functions performed previously by the cruising ships (sailing frigates and sloops) of the Age of Sail.
words.name: Cruiser

words.def: Metal Y shaped pins to hold oars whilst rowing.
words.name: Crutches

words.def: A small cabin in a boat; a cabin, for the use of the captain, in the after part of a sailing ship under the poop deck.
words.name: Cuddy

words.def: A line invented by Briggs Cunningham, used to control the shape of a sail.
words.name: Cunningham

words.def: A join between two lines, similar to an eye-splice, where each rope end is joined to the other a short distance along, making an opening which closes under tension.
words.name: Cunt splice or cut splice

words.def: The "valley" between the strands of a rope or cable. Before serving a section of laid rope e.g. to protect it from chafing, it may be "wormed" by laying yarns in the cuntlines, giving that section an even cylindrical shape.
words.name: Cuntline

words.def: When wanting to make a quick escape, a ship might cut lashings to sails or cables for anchors, causing damage to the rigging, or losing an anchor, but shortening the time needed to make ready by bypassing the proper procedures.
words.name: Cut and run

words.def: The "cut" of a sail refers to its shape. Since this would vary between ships, it could be used both to identify a familiar vessel at a distance, and to judge the possible sailing qualities of an unknown one. Also used figuratively of people.[15]
words.name: Cut of his jib

words.def: 1.  A small single-masted boat, fore-and-aft rigged, with two or more headsails and often a bowsprit. The mast is set farther back than on a sloop.
words.name: Cutter

words.def: A type of light centerboard that is lifted vertically; often in pairs, with the leeward one lowered when beating.
words.name: Daggerboard

words.def: 1.  A spar formerly used on board ships as a crane to hoist the flukes of the anchor to the top of the bow, without injuring the sides of the ship.
words.name: Davit

words.def: An idiom for the bottom of the sea.
words.name: Davy Jones' Locker

words.def: An unlighted fixed structure which is equipped with a dayboard for daytime identification.
words.name: Day beacon

words.def: Moment at dawn where, from some point on the mast, a lookout can see above low lying mist which envelops the ship.
words.name: Day-blink

words.def: The daytime identifier of an aid to navigation presenting one of several standard shapes (square, triangle, rectangle) and colors (red, green, white, orange, yellow, or black).
words.name: Dayboard

words.def: Exactly ahead, directly ahead, directly in front.
words.name: Dead ahead

words.def: Not moving (used only when a vessel is afloat and neither tied up nor anchored).
words.name: Dead in the water

words.def: See running.
words.name: Dead run

words.def: The trail of a fading disturbance in the water. See also wake.
words.name: Dead wake

words.def: A wooden block with holes (but no pulleys) which is spliced to a shroud. It is used to adjust the tension in the standing rigging of large sailing vessels, by lacing through the holes with a lanyard to the deck. Performs the same job as a turnbuckle.
words.name: Deadeye

words.def: A strong shutter fitted over a porthole or other opening that can be closed in bad weather.
words.name: Deadlight

words.def: The design angle between the keel (q.v.) and horizontal.
words.name: Deadrise

words.def: A wooden part (vertical timbers or planking) of the centerline structure of a boat, usually between the sternpost and amidships. It is used to "fill the spaces where, owing to the shape of the vessel, the floor-timbers have to be discontinued."[16][17]
words.name: Deadwood

words.def: In a keel boat, a death roll is the act of broaching to windward, putting the spinnaker pole into the water and causing a crash-gybe of the boom and mainsail, which sweep across the deck and plunge down into the water. During a death roll, the boat rolls from side to side, becoming gradually more unstable until either it capsizes or the skipper reacts correctly to prevent it.
words.name: Death roll

words.def: The process of leaving a ship or aircraft, or removing goods from a ship or aircraft.
words.name: Debarcation or disembarkation

words.def: The process of removing fuel from a vessel. After a ship wreck, a "debunkering" operation will be performed in an effort to minimize damage and protect the environment from fuel spills.
words.name: Debunk

words.def: The top of the boat; the surface is removed to accommodate the seating area. The structures forming the approximately horizontal surfaces in the ship's general structure. Unlike flats, they are a structural part of the ship.
words.name: Decks

words.def: A person whose job involves aiding the deck supervisor in (un)mooring, anchoring, maintenance, and general evolutions on deck.
words.name: Deck hand or decky

words.def: The person in charge of all evolutions and maintenance on deck; sometimes split into two groups: forward deck supervisor, aft deck supervisor.
words.name: Deck supervisor

words.def: The under-side of the deck above. The inside of the boat is normally paneled over to hide the structure, pipes, electrical wires. It can be in thin wood planks, often covered with a vinyl lining, or in thin PVC or now even in fiberglass planks.
words.name: Deckhead

words.def: A situation in which the deck of the vessel is partially or wholly submerged, possibly as a result of excessive listing or a loss of buoyancy.
words.name: Decks awash

words.def: To formally take (a naval vessel) out of active service, after which the vessel is said to be out of commission or decommissioned. Sometimes used less formally to mean taking a commercial ship out of service.
words.name: Decommission

words.def: A ship which acts as a mobile or fixed base for other ships and submarines or supports a naval base.
words.name: Depot ship

words.def: The height from the lowest part of the hull inside the ship, at its midpoint, to the ceiling that is made up of the uppermost full length deck. For old warships it is to the ceiling that is made up of the lowermost full length deck.
words.name: Depth of hold

words.def: A lifting device composed of one mast or pole and a boom or jib which is hinged freely at the bottom.
words.name: Derrick

words.def: Alternative spelling of dispatch boat.
words.name: Despatch boat

words.def: A type of fast and maneuverable small warship introduced in the 1890s to protect capital ships from torpedo boat attack, since increased in size and capabilities to become a long-endurance warship intended to escort larger vessels in a fleet, convoy, or battle group and defend them against submarines, surface ships, aircraft, and missiles.
words.name: Destroyer (originally torpedo boat destroyer)

words.def: The United States Navy term for a smaller, lightly armed warship built in large numbers during World War II (and ins smaller numbers thereafter), cheaper, slower, and less-well-armed than a destroyer but larger and more heavily armed than a corvette and designed to escort convoys of merchant ships or naval auxiliaries or second-line naval forces. Employed primarily for anti-submarine warfare, but also provided some protection against aircraft and smaller surface ships. Generally known as "frigates" in other navies, and designated as such in the U.S. Navy as well by the 1970s.
words.name: Destroyer escort

words.def: A large destroyer suitable for commanding a flotilla of destroyers or other small warships; a type of flotilla leader.
words.name: Destroyer leader

words.def: The devil was possibly a slang term for the garboard seam, hence "between the devil and the deep blue sea" being an allusion to keel hauling, but a more popular version seems to be the seam between the waterway and the stanchions which would be difficult to get at, requiring a cranked caulking iron, and a restricted swing of the caulking mallet.
words.name: Devil seam

words.def: "Paying" the devil is sealing the devil seam. It is a difficult and unpleasant job (with no resources) because of the shape of the seam (up against the stanchions) or if the devil refers to the garboard seam, it must be done with the ship slipped or careened.
words.name: Devil to pay (or Devil to pay, and no pitch hot)

words.def: the generic name of a number of traditional sailing vessels with one or more masts with lateen sails used in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean region, typically weighing 300 to 500 tons, with a long, thin hull. They are trading vessels primarily used to carry heavy items, like fruit, fresh water or merchandise. Crews vary from about thirty to around twelve, depending on the size of the vessel.
words.name: Dhow

words.def: 1.  A type of small boat, often carried or towed as a ship's boat by a larger vessel.
words.name: Dinghy

words.def: A light illuminating a sector or very narrow angle and intended to mark a direction to be followed.
words.name: Directional light

words.def:
Dipping the eye


Method of attaching more than one hawser to a single bollard, so that each can be lifted off without disturbing the other(s). The second hawser is passed under the first, then up through the eye of the first (hence the name), before being secured over the bollard.
words.name: Dipping the eye

words.def: A vessel ranging in size from a small boat to a large ship tasked to carry military dispatches from ship to ship, from ship to shore, or, occasionally, from shore to shore.
words.name: Dispatch boat

words.def: The weight of water displaced by the immersed volume of a ship's hull, exactly equivalent to the weight of the whole ship.
words.name: Displacement

words.def: A hull designed to travel through the water, rather than planing over it.
words.name: Displacement hull

words.def: To reduce in rank or rating; demote.
words.name: Disrate

words.def: A flag flown to distinguish ships of one seagoing service of a given country from ships of the country's other seagoing service(s) when ships of more than one of the country's seagoing services fly the same ensign.
words.name: Distinguishing mark

words.def: 1.  In American usage, a fixed structure attached to shore to which a vessel is secured when in port, generally synonymous with pier and wharf, except that pier tends to refer to structures used for tying up commercial ships and to structures extending from shore for use in fishing, while dock refers more generally to facilities used for tying up ships or boats, including recreational craft.
words.name: Dock

words.def: A facility where ships or boats are built and repaired. Routinely used as a synonym for shipyard, although dockyard sometimes is associated more closely with a facility used for maintenance and basing activities, while shipyard sometimes is associated more closely with a facility used in construction.
words.name: Dockyard

words.def: A hood forward of a hatch or cockpit to protect the crew from wind and spray. Can be soft or hard.
words.name: Dodger

words.def: A short watch period, generally half the usual time (e.g. a two-hour watch rather than a four-hour one). Such watches might be included in order to rotate the system over different days for fairness, or to allow both watches to eat their meals at approximately normal times.
words.name: Dog watch

words.def: A slang term (in the US, mostly) for a raised portion of a ship's deck. A doghouse is usually added to improve headroom below or to shelter a hatch.
words.name: Doghouse

words.def: A small weather vane, sometimes improvised with a scrap of cloth, yarn or other light material mounted within sight of the helmsman. (See tell-tale)
words.name: Dogvane

words.def: The equatorial trough, with special reference to the light and variable nature of the winds.[18]
words.name: Doldrums or equatorial calms

words.def: A structure consisting of a number of piles driven into the seabed or riverbed as a marker.
words.name: Dolphin

words.def: A small auxiliary engine used either to start a larger engine or independently, e.g. for pumping water on steamships.[19]
words.name: Donkey engine

words.def: One of a ship's engineering crew. Often a crewman responsible for maintaining a Steam donkey, or any machinery other than the main engines. On some ships, the Petty Officer in charge of engineroom ratings.
words.name: Donkeyman

words.def: A shallow-draft, lightweight boat, about 5 to 7 metres long, with high sides, a flat bottom and sharp bows. Traditionally used as fishing boats, both in coastal waters and in the open sea.
words.name: Dory or doree, dori, or (RN) dorey

words.def: The practice of loading smooth-bore cannon with two cannon-balls.
words.name: Double-shotted

words.def: Very rough seas with large white capped waves.
words.name: Dover Cliffs

words.def: 1.  A vessel traveling downstream.
words.name: Downbound

words.def: A line used to control either a mobile spar, or the shape of a sail. A downhaul can also be used to retrieve a sail back on deck.
words.name: Downhaul

words.def: An extra strip of canvas secured below a bonnet (q.v.), further to increase the area of a course
words.name: Drabbler

words.def: The depth of a ship's keel below the waterline.
words.name: Draft or draught (both /ˈdrɑːft/)

words.def: One of a family of traditional paddled long boats of various designs and sizes found throughout Asia, Africa and the Pacific Islands. For competitive events, they are generally rigged with decorative Chinese dragon heads and tails. Dragon boat races are traditionally held during the annual summer solstice festival.
words.name: Dragon boat (also dragonboat)

words.def: A type of battleship designed with an "all-big-gun" armament layout in which the ship's primary gun power resided in a primary battery of its largest guns intended for use at long range, with other gun armament limited to small weapons intended for close-range defense against torpedo boats and other small warships. Most, but not all, dreadnoughts also had steam turbine propulsion. Predominant from 1906, dreadnoughts differed from earlier steam battleships, retroactively dubbed "predreadnoughts", which had only a few large guns, relied on an intermediate secondary battery used at shorter ranges for most of their offensive power, and had triple-expansion steam engines.
words.name: Dreadnought

words.def: To string International Code of Signals flags, arranged at random, from masthead to masthead (if the vessel has more than one mast) and then down to the taffrail, on a ship in harbor as a sign of celebration of a national, local, or personal anniversary, event, holiday, or occasion. When a ship is properly dressed overall, ensigns fly at each masthead unless displaced by another flag – for example, that of a flag officer on board – in addition to the ensign flown in the usual position at the stern.
words.name: Dress overall

words.def: 1.  Treating old sails with oil or wax to renew them.
words.name: Dressing down

words.def: A type of fishing boat designed to catch herring in a long drift net, long used in the Netherlands and Great Britain.
words.name: Drifter

words.def: Overboard and into the water, as it fell into the drink.
words.name: Drink

words.def: The large sail flown from the mizzen gaff.
words.name: Driver

words.def: The fifth mast of a six-masted barquentine or gaff schooner. It is preceded by the jigger mast and followed by the spanker mast. The sixth mast of the only seven-masted vessel, the gaff schooner Thomas W. Lawson, was normally called the pusher-mast.
words.name: Driver-mast

words.def: A device to slow a boat down in a storm so that it does not speed excessively down the slope of a wave and crash into the next one. It is generally constructed of heavy flexible material in the shape of a cone. See also sea anchor.
words.name: Drogue /ˈdroʊɡ/

words.def: A narrow basin or vessel used for the construction, maintenance, and repair of ships, boats, and other watercraft that can be flooded to allow a load to be floated in, then drained to allow that load to come to rest on a dry platform.
words.name: Drydock

words.def: 1.  Loose packing material used to protect a ship's cargo from damage during transport. (See also fardage)
words.name: Dunnage /ˈdʌnᵻdʒ/

words.def: A part on a ship that has no use.
words.name: Dunsel

words.def: Small lines, by which the uppermost corners of the largest sails are secured to the yardarms.
words.name: Earings

words.def: Any ship operating under charter or license to the East India Company (England), or to the Danish East India Company, French East India Company, Dutch East India Company, Portuguese East India Company, or Swedish East India Company from the 17th to the 19th centuries.
words.name: East Indiaman

words.def: Measuring the depth of the water using a sonar device. See also sounding and swinging the lead.
words.name: Echo sounding

words.def: The condition where a sailing vessel (especially one which sails poorly to windward) is confined between two capes or headlands by a wind blowing directly onshore.
words.name: Embayed

words.def:
An arrangement of gun turrets whereby the turret on one side of the ship is placed further aft than the one on the other side, so that both turrets can fire to either side.




Diagram showing the Minas Geraes-class battleship with its central guns arranged en echelon.
words.name: En echelon

words.def: A communications device used by the pilot to order engineers in the engine room to power the vessel at a certain desired speed. Also Chadburn.
words.name: Engine order telegraph

words.def: One of the machinery spaces of a vessel, usually the largest one, containing the ship's prime mover (usually a diesel or steam engine or a gas or steam turbine). Larger vessels may have more than one engine room.
words.name: Engine room

words.def: 1.  Ensign, the principal flag or banner flown by a ship to indicate her nationality.
words.name: Ensign

words.def: An aircraft carrier, smaller and slower than a fleet carrier, used by some navies in World War II to escort convoys, ferry aircraft, and provide air support for amphibious operations.
words.name: Escort carrier

words.def: (also known as "in extremis") the point under International Rules of the Road (Navigation Rules) at which the privileged (or stand-on) vessel on collision course with a burdened (or give-way) vessel determines it must maneuver to avoid a collision. Prior to extremis, the privileged vessel must maintain course and speed and the burdened vessel must maneuver to avoid collision.
words.name: Extremis

words.def: A closed loop or eye at the end a line, rope, cable, etc. It is made by unraveling its end and joining it to itself by intertwining it into the lay of the line. Eye splices are very strong and compact and are employed in moorings and docking lines among other uses.
words.name: Eye splice

words.def: A large ocean-going vessel with extensive on-board facilities for processing and freezing caught fish or whales. Some also serve as mother ships (q.v.) for smaller fishing or whaling vessels. Those used for processing fish are also known as fish processing vessels.
words.name: Factory ship

words.def: 1.  A smooth curve, usually referring to a line of the hull which has no deviations.
words.name: Fair

words.def: A blessing wishing the recipient a safe journey and good fortune.
words.name: Fair winds and following seas

words.def: A ring, hook or other device used to keep a line or chain running in the correct direction or to prevent it rubbing or fouling.
words.name: Fairlead

words.def: A structure that improves the streamlining of a vessel.
words.name: Fairwater

words.def: A traditional fishing boat with a lateen sail on a single mast used by fishermen from the town of Komiža on the Adriatic island of Vis.
words.name: Falkuša

words.def: The part of the tackle that is hauled upon.
words.name: Fall

words.def: To change the direction of sail so as to point in a direction that is more down wind. To bring the bow leeward. Also bear away, bear off or head down. This is the opposite of pointing up or heading up.
words.name: Fall off

words.def: Aft end of the ship, also known as the Poop deck.
words.name: Fantail

words.def: Wood placed in bottom of ship to keep cargo dry. (See also dunnage)
words.name: Fardage

words.def: Fastened or held firmly (fast aground: stuck on the seabed; made fast: tied securely).
words.name: Fast

words.def: A unit of length equal to 6 feet (1.8 m), roughly measured as the distance between a man's outstretched hands. Particularly used to measure depth.
words.name: Fathom /ˈfæðəm/

words.def: A depth finder that uses sound waves to determine the depth of water.
words.name: Fathometer

words.def: A traditional wooden sailing boat with a rig consisting of one or two lateen sails, used in protected waters of the Red Sea and eastern Mediterranean and particularly along the Nile in Egypt and Sudan, and also in Iraq.
words.name: Felucca

words.def: A command given to the crew to stop what they are now doing and to immediately manually prevent the boat from banging into the docks or other boats.
words.name: Fend Off

words.def: An air or foam filled bumper used in boating to keep boats from banging into docks or each other.
words.name: Fender

words.def: 1.  The distance across water which a wind or waves have traveled.
words.name: Fetch
