words.def: 1.  A tapered wooden tool used for separating the strands of rope for splicing.
words.name: Fid

words.def: A freestanding pinrail surrounding the base of a mast and used for securing that mast's sails' halyards with a series of belaying pins.
words.name: Fife rail

words.def: A sailing boat with two masts with a standard rig consisting of a main dipping lugsail and a mizzen standing lug sail developed in Scotland; used for commercial fishing from the 1850s until the 20th century.
words.name: Fifie

words.def: U.S. Navy slang for a guided-missile frigate, especially of the Oliver Hazard Perry class, derived from its class designation ("FFG").
words.name: Fig

words.def: An enlarged top designed to allow gunfire downward onto an enemy ship. A fighting top could have small guns installed in it or could serve as a platform for snipers armed with muskets or rifles.
words.name: Fighting top

words.def: A symbolic image at the head of a traditional sailing ship or early steamer.
words.name: Figurehead

words.def: A term used in European and British Commonwealth countries for a tower-like structure on the dorsal (topside) surface of a submarine; called a sail in the United States.
words.name: Fin

words.def: Narrow (fine) in appearance from the vantage point of a lookout or other person viewing activity in the vicinity of a ship, e.g., another ship off the starboard bow with her bow or stern facing the viewer's ship could be described as "fine on the starboard bow" of the viewer's ship.
words.name: Fine

words.def: A ship loaded with flammable materials and explosives and sailed into an enemy port or fleet either already burning or ready to be set alight by its crew (who would then abandon it) in order to collide with and set fire to enemy ships.
words.name: Fire ship

words.def: The compartment in which the ship's boilers or furnaces are stoked and fired.
words.name: Fire room, also boiler room

words.def: The classification for the largest sailing warships of the 17th through 19th centuries. They had 3 masts, 850+ crew and 100+ guns.
words.name: First-rate

words.def: 1.  In the Royal Navy, the senior lieutenant on board; responsible to the commanding officer for the domestic affairs of the ship's company. Also known as 'Jimmy the One' or 'Number One'. Removes his cap when visiting the mess decks as token of respect for the privacy of the crew in those quarters. Officer in charge of cables on the forecastle.
words.name: First lieutenant

words.def: The second-in-command of a commercial ship.
words.name: First mate

words.def: 1.  To repair a mast or spar with a fillet of wood.
words.name: Fish

words.def: A sailing tactic for handling winds too strong for the sail area hoisted when reefing the sails is not feasible or possible. The headsail is set normally while the mainsail is let out till it is constantly luffing. This creates loss of force on the main and also reduces the efficiency of the headsail while still retaining sailing control of the vessel.
words.name: Fisherman's reef

words.def: The period after a ship is launched during which all the remaining construction of the ship is completed and she is readied for sea trials and delivery to her owners.
words.name: Fitting-out

words.def: A propeller mounted on a rigid shaft protruding from the hull of a vessel, usually driven by an inboard motor; steering must be done using a rudder. See also outboard motor and sterndrive.
words.name: Fixed propeller

words.def: A number of signal flags strung together to convey a message, e.g., 'England expects...'
words.name: Flag hoist

words.def: The business practice of registering a merchant ship in a sovereign state different from that of the ship's owners, and flying that state's civil ensign on the ship. The practice allows the ship's owner to reduce operating costs or avoid the regulations of the owner's country.
words.name: Flag of convenience

words.def: 1.  A commissioned officer senior enough to be entitled to fly a flag to mark the ship or installation from which he or she exercises command, in English-speaking countries usually referring to the senior officers of a navy, specifically those who hold any of the admiral ranks and in some cases to those holding the rank of commodore. In modern American usage, additionally applied to U.S. Coast Guard and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Corps officers and general officers in the U.S. Army, U.S. Air Force, and U.S. Marine Corps entitled to fly their own flags.
words.name: Flag officer

words.def: 1.  A vessel used by the commanding officer of a group of naval ships. The term derives from the custom of the commander of such a group of ships, characteristically a flag officer, flying a distinguishing flag aboard the ship on which he or she is embarked.
words.name: Flagship

words.def: The maximum speed of a ship. Faster than "full speed".
words.name: Flank

words.def: 1.  A curvature of the topsides outward towards the gunwale.
words.name: Flare

words.def: A Great Lakes slang term for a vessel without any self-unloading equipment.
words.name: Flatback

words.def: Slang term for an aircraft carrier (q.v.).
words.name: Flattop

words.def: To coil a line that is not in use so that it lies flat on the deck.
words.name: Flemish

words.def: A flat deck used for the launch and recovery of aircraft.
words.name: Flight deck

words.def: A warship suitable for commanding a flotilla of destroyers or other small warships, typically a small cruiser or a large destroyer, in the latter case known as a destroyer leader.
words.name: Flotilla leader

words.def: Debris or cargo that remains afloat after a shipwreck. See also jetsam.
words.name: Flotsam

words.def: The wedge-shaped part of an anchor's arms that digs into the bottom.
words.name: Fluke

words.def: An upper deck of a vessel that extends unbroken from stem to stern.
words.name: Flush deck

words.def: 1.  A United States Navy destroyer of the World War I-era Caldwell, Wickes, or Clemson class, produced in very large numbers.
words.name: Flush decker

words.def: A Dutch transoceanic sailing cargo vessel, square-rigged with two or three masts that were much taller than the masts of a galleon, developed in the 16th century and widely used in the 17th and 18th centuries.
words.name: Fluyt (also fluit or flute)

words.def: A large sail used only for sailing downwind, requiring little attention.
words.name: Fly by night

words.def: A propeller with folding blades, furling to reduce drag on a sailing vessel when not in use.
words.name: Folding propeller

words.def: Wave or tidal movement going in the same direction as a ship
words.name: Following sea

words.def: An impromptu musical band on late 19th-century sailing vessels, made up from members of the ship's crew[20][21]
words.name: Foo-foo band

words.def: 1.  The lower edge of any sail.
words.name: Foot

words.def: If the foot of a sail is not secured properly, it is footloose, blowing around in the wind.
words.name: Footloose

words.def: Each yard on a square rigged sailing ship is equipped with a footrope for sailors to stand on while setting or stowing the sails
words.name: Footrope

words.def: See Beaufort scale.
words.name: Force

words.def: Towards the bow (of the vessel).
words.name: Fore, forward (/ˈfɒrərd/, and often written "for'ard")

words.def: A sailing rig consisting mainly of sails that are set along the line of the keel rather than perpendicular to it. Such sails are referred to as "fore-and-aft rigged."
words.name: Fore-and-aft rig

words.def: A partial deck, above the upper deck and at the head of the vessel; traditionally the sailors' living quarters. Pronounced /ˈfoʊksəl/. The name is derived from the castle fitted to bear archers in time of war.
words.name: Forecastle

words.def: The lower part of the stem of a ship.
words.name: Forefoot

words.def: An enlisted sailor, one who is housed before the foremast.
words.name: Foremast jack

words.def: The part of the hold of a ship within the angle of the bow.
words.name: Forepeak

words.def: Long lines or cables, reaching from the bow of the vessel to the mast heads, used to support the mast.
words.name: Forestays

words.def: 1.  Having freedom of motion interfered with by collision or entanglement; entangled; the opposite of clear. For instance, a rope is foul when it does not run straight or smoothly, and an anchor is foul when it is caught on an obstruction.
words.name: Foul

words.def: Slang for oilskins, the foul-weather clothing worn by sailors. See also oilskins.
words.name: Foulies

words.def: To fill with water and sink → Founder (Wiktionary)
words.name: Founder

words.def: In the British Royal Navy, a fourth rate was, during the first half of the 18th century, a ship of the line mounting from 46 up to 60 guns.
words.name: Fourth rate

words.def: A transverse structural member which gives the hull strength and shape. Wooden frames may be sawn, bent or laminated into shape. Planking is then fastened to the frames. A bent frame is called a timber.
words.name: Frame

words.def: The height of a ship's hull (excluding superstructure) above the waterline. The vertical distance from the current waterline to the lowest point on the highest continuous watertight deck. This usually varies from one part to another.
words.name: Freeboard

words.def: A cargo ship.
words.name: Freighter

words.def: 1.  In the 17th century, any warship built for speed and maneuverability.
words.name: Frigate

words.def: Sailing into the wind (by), but not as close-hauled as might be possible, so as to make sure the sails are kept full. This provides a margin for error to avoid being taken aback (a serious risk for square-rigged vessels) in a tricky sea. Figuratively it implies getting on with the job but in a steady, relaxed way, without undue urgency or strain.
words.name: Full and by

words.def: A sailing vessel with three or more masts, all of them square-rigged. A full-rigged ship is said to have a "ship rig".
words.name: Full-rigged ship

words.def: The smokestack of a ship, used to expel boiler steam and smoke or engine exhaust.
words.name: Funnel (also stack)

words.def: To roll or gather a sail against its mast or spar.
words.name: Furl

words.def: A narrow, light, and fast ship with shallow draft, powered by both oars and sail, with a single mast carrying a lateen sail; a favorite of North African corsairs during the 16th and 17th centuries.
words.name: Fusta (also fuste, foist, or galliot)

words.def: Pieces of timber that make up a large transverse frame.
words.name: Futtocks

words.def: 1.  Gaff rig: The spar that holds the upper edge of a four-sided fore-and-aft mounted sail.
words.name: Gaff

words.def: A boat rigged with a four-sided fore-and-aft sail with its upper edge supported by a spar or gaff which extends aft from the mast.
words.name: Gaff rigged

words.def: A line rigged to the end of a gaff and used to adjust a gaff sail's trim.
words.name: Gaff vang

words.def: 1.  An oared warship of the 1500s equipped with a gundeck, larger and equipped with more sails than a galley.
words.name: Galleass

words.def: A large, multi-decked sailing ship used primarily by European states from the 16th to 18th centuries.
words.name: Galleon

words.def: 1.  Galley, the kitchen of a ship.
words.name: Galley

words.def: See fusta.
words.name: Galliot

words.def: A meeting of two (or more) whaling ships at sea. The ships each send out a boat to the other, and the two captains meet on one ship, while the two chief mates meet on the other.[22]
words.name: Gam

words.def: The bow fitting which clamps the bowsprit to the stem.
words.name: Gammon iron

words.def: A movable bridge used in boarding or leaving a ship at a pier; also known as a "brow".
words.name: Gangplank

words.def: An opening in the bulwark of the ship to allow passengers to board or leave the ship.
words.name: Gangway

words.def: The (illegal) practice of mixing cargo with garbage.
words.name: Garbling

words.def: The strake closest to the keel (from Dutch gaarboard).
words.name: Garboard

words.def: The planks immediately either side of the keel.
words.name: Garboard planks

words.def: Any refuse or rubbish which is discarded into a refuse container or dustbin which is known as "gash fanny" (South African Navy).
words.name: Gash

words.def: Refuse container or dustbin.
words.name: Gash Fanny

words.def: See Battle Stations.
words.name: General Quarters

words.def: A large, lightweight sail used for sailing a fore-and-aft rig down or across the wind, intermediate between a genoa and a spinnaker.
words.name: Gennaker

words.def: A large jib, strongly overlapping the mainmast.
words.name: Genoa or genny (both /ˈdʒɛni/)

words.def: To sail slowly when there is apparently no wind.
words.name: Ghost

words.def: See gybe.
words.name: Gibe

words.def: A boat on naval ships at the disposal of the ship's captain for his or her use in transportation to other ships or to the shore.
words.name: Gig (Captain's gig)

words.def: A pole that is attached perpendicular to the mast, to be used as a lever for raising the mast. Also jin-pole.
words.name: Gin-pole

words.def: Where two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve a risk of collision, this is the vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of the other.
words.name: Give-way (vessel)

words.def: A marine barometer. (Older barometers used mercury-filled glass tubes to measure and indicate barometric pressure.)
words.name: Glass

words.def: (GPS) A satellite based radionavigation system providing continuous worldwide coverage. It provides navigation, position, and timing information to air, marine, and land users.
words.name: Global Positioning System

words.def: is a small, fast boat designed with a long narrow platform and a planing hull to enable it to reach high speeds – also called 'a rum-runner', or, more recently, 'a cigarette boat'.
words.name: Go-fast boat

words.def: a mess hall reserved for Chief petty officers in the U.S. Navy
words.name: Goat locker

words.def: Changing from one tack to another by going through the wind (see also gybe).
words.name: Going about or tacking

words.def: A traditional, flat-bottomed Venetian rowing boat.
words.name: Gondola

words.def: Fitting that attaches the boom to the mast, allowing it to move freely.
words.name: Gooseneck

words.def: Of a fore-and-aft rigged vessel sailing directly away from the wind, with the sails set on opposite sides of the vessel—for example with the mainsail to port and the jib to starboard, to maximize the amount of canvas exposed to the wind. See also running.
words.name: Goosewinged

words.def: Small balls of lead fired from a cannon, analogous to shotgun shot but on a larger scale. Similar to canister shot but with larger individual shot. Used to injure personnel and damage rigging more than to cause structural damage.
words.name: Grapeshot

words.def: To clean a ship's bottom.
words.name: Grave

words.def: A narrow basin, usually made of earthen berms and concrete, closed by gates or by a caisson, into which a vessel may be floated and the water pumped out, leaving the vessel supported on blocks; the classic form of drydock.
words.name: Graving dock

words.def: A passage of two vessels moving in the opposite direction on their starboard sides, so called because the green navigation light on one of the vessels faces the green light on the other vessel.
words.name: Green-to-green

words.def: Temporary eye in a line(rope).
words.name: Gripe

words.def: Watered-down pusser's rum consisting of half a gill with equal part of water, issued to all seamen over twenty. (CPOs and POs were issued with neat rum) From the British Admiral Vernon who, in 1740, ordered the men's ration of rum to be watered down. He was called "Old Grogram" because he often wore a grogram coat, and the watered rum came to be called 'grog'. Often used (illegally) as currency in exchange for favours in quantities prescribed as 'sippers' and 'gulpers'. Additional issues of grog were made on the command 'splice the mainbrace' for celebrations or as a reward for performing especially onerous duties. The RN discontinued the practice of issuing rum in 1970. A sailor might repay a colleague for a favour by giving him part or all of his grog ration, ranging from "sippers" (a small amount) via "gulpers" (a larger quantity) to "grounders" (the entire tot).
words.name: Grog

words.def: Drunk from having consumed a lot of grog.
words.name: Groggy

words.def: The bed of the sea.
words.name: Ground

words.def: When a ship (while afloat) touches the bed of the sea, or goes "aground" (q.v.).
words.name: Grounding

words.def: A small iceberg or ice floe which is barely visible above the surface of the water.
words.name: Growler

words.def: A boat which makes the rounds of a fleet at anchor to see that due watch is kept at night.
words.name: Guard boat

words.def: 1.  A warship stationed at a port or harbour to act as a guard there.
words.name: Guard ship

words.def: 1.  Up through the 19th century, a deck aboard a ship that was primarily used for the mounting of cannon to be fired in broadsides.
words.name: Gun deck

words.def: see Kissing the gunner's daughter.
words.name: Gunner's daughter

words.def: The opening in the side of the ship or in a turret through which the gun fires or protrudes.
words.name: Gunport

words.def: Upper edge of the hull.
words.name: Gunwale /ˈɡʌnəl/

words.def: To change from one tack to the other away from the wind, with the stern of the vessel turning through the wind. (See also going about and wearing ship.)
words.name: Gybe or jibe (both /ˈdʒaɪb/)

words.def: In shipbuilding, an elevation of the lines of a ship, viewed from above and divided lengthwise.
words.name: Half-breadth plan

words.def: Originally, ropes used for hoisting a spar with a sail attached; today, a line used to raise the head of any sail.
words.name: Halyard or halliard

words.def: Canvas sheets, slung from the deckhead in messdecks, in which seamen slept. "Lash up and stow" a piped command to tie up hammocks and stow them (typically) in racks inboard of the ship's side to protect crew from splinters from shot and provide a ready means of preventing flooding caused by damage.
words.name: Hammock

words.def: To furl a sail.
words.name: Hand

words.def: A ship using coal-fired boilers shoveled in by hand.
words.name: Hand bomber

words.def: To climb steadily upwards, from the motion of a sailor climbing shrouds on a sailing ship (originally "hand over hand").
words.name: Hand over fist

words.def: With a slow even motion, as when hauling on a line "handsomely".
words.name: Handsomely

words.def: A loose block and tackle with a hook or tail on each end, which can be used wherever it is needed. Usually made up of one single and one double block.
words.name: Handy billy

words.def: An enclosed deck, usually beneath the flight deck, on an aircraft carrier intended for use as a hangar in servicing and storing aircraft.
words.name: Hangar deck

words.def: A fastener attached to the luff of the headsail that attaches the headsail to the forestay. Typical designs include a bronze or plastic hook with a spring-operated gate, or a strip of cloth webbing with a snap fastener.
words.name: Hank

words.def: A harbor or harbour, or haven, is a place where ships may shelter from the weather or are stored. Harbours can be man-made or natural.
words.name: Harbor

words.def: A place where ships in transit can find shelter from a storm. These are often man-made jetty enclosed areas along a featureless coastline where no nearby natural deep water harbors exist.
words.name: Harbor of refuge

words.def: A section of otherwise muddy shoreline suitable for mooring or hauling out.
words.name: Hard

words.def: See lee-oh.
words.name: Hard-a-lee

words.def: Turn towards the wind; sail closer to the wind.
words.name: Harden up

words.def: A large usually round tub lashed to a vessel's deck and containing dried and salted provisions for daily use.
words.name: Harness cask

words.def: See "harness cask".
words.name: Harness tub

words.def: A hard and long-lasting dry biscuit, used as food on long journeys. Also called ship's biscuit.
words.name: Hardtack

words.def: A covered opening in a ship's deck through which cargo can be loaded or access made to a lower deck; the cover to the opening is called a hatch.
words.name: Hatchway, hatch

words.def: 1.  To steer (a vessel) closer to the direction of the wind.
words.name: Haul

words.def: Pointing the ship towards the direction of the wind; generally not the fastest point of travel on a sailing vessel.
words.name: Hauling wind

words.def: The shaft or hole in the side of a vessel's bow through which the anchor chain passes.
words.name: Hawsepipe, hawsehole or hawse /ˈhɔːz/

words.def: An informal term for a merchant ship's officer who began their career as an unlicensed merchant seaman, and so did not attend a traditional maritime academy to earn their officer's licence (see also before the mast).
words.name: Hawsepiper

words.def: Large rope used for mooring or towing a vessel.
words.name: Hawser

words.def: 1.  The forwardmost or uppermost portion of the ship.
words.name: Head

words.def: A fishing boat that takes recreational fishermen out for a fee paid individually by each person (i.e., per head). A head boat differs from a charter boat, which is a fishing boat that a party of fishermen hires for an agreed-upon period.
words.name: Head boat

words.def: The farthest point above the mouth of a river that can be navigated by ships.
words.name: Head of navigation

words.def: A curved rail that extends from the figurehead to the bow of a ship.
words.name: Head rail

words.def: A sea where waves are directly opposing the motion of the ship.
words.name: Head sea

words.def: A change in the wind direction which forces the helmsman of a close hauled sailboat to steer away from its current course to a less favorable one. This is the opposite of a lift.
words.name: Header

words.def: The direction a thing's nose is pointing.
words.name: Heading content=Heading

words.def: Any sail flown in front of the most forward mast.
words.name: Headsail

words.def: A vessel's transient, vertical, up-and-down motion.
words.name: Heave

words.def: Turn a ship on its side (for cleaning). Also known as Careening
words.name: Heave down

words.def: Or Hove to. Stopping a sailing vessel by lashing the helm in opposition to the sails. The vessel will gradually drift to leeward, the speed of the drift depending on the vessel's design.
words.name: Heaving to

words.def: 1.  The lean caused by the wind's force on the sails of a sailing vessel.
words.name: Heel

words.def: A ship's steering mechanism; see tiller and ship's wheel. The wheel and/or wheelhouse area. See also wheelhouse.
words.name: Helm

words.def: A person who steers a ship.
words.name: Helmsman

words.def: A type of seagoing fishing vessel used by Dutch and Flemish herring fishermen from the 15th through the early 19th century.
words.name: Herring buss

words.def: A particular type of tensioning lever, usually for running backstays. Their use allows the leeward backstay to be completely slackened so that the boom can be let fully out.
words.name: Highfield lever

words.def: A knot used to tie a rope or line to a fixed object. See also bend.
words.name: Hitch

words.def: 1.  A fore-and-aft structural member of the hull fitted over the keel to provide a fixing for the garboard planks.
words.name: Hog

words.def: When the peak of a wave is amidships, causing the hull to bend so the ends of the keel are lower than the middle. The opposite of sagging. Also refers to a permanent distortion of the hull in the same manner caused, over time, by the bow and stern of a ship being less buoyant than the midships section. During the Age of Sail, shipwrights employed a number of different designs of braces to stiffen ships' hulls against this warping.
words.name: Hogging

words.def: The height of a fore-and-aft sail as measured next to the mast or stay.
words.name: Hoist

words.def: In earlier use, below the orlop deck, the lower part of the interior of a ship's hull, especially when considered as storage space, as for cargo. In later merchant vessels it extended up through the decks to the underside of the weather deck.
words.name: Hold

words.def: A gap in the coverage of newly applied paint, slush, tar or other preservative.
words.name: Holiday

words.def: A chunk of sandstone used to scrub the decks. The name comes from both the kneeling position sailors adopt to scrub the deck (reminiscent of genuflection for prayer), and the stone itself (which resembled a Bible in shape and size).
words.name: Holystone

words.def: The port at which a vessel is based. Often confused with the ship's port of registry, which is the port listed in the vessel's registration documents and lettered on her stern and which may differ from her home port. In the cruise ship industry, the term "home port" often is mistakenly used to refer to a ship's port of departure.
words.name: Home port

words.def: A sound signal which uses electricity or compressed air to vibrate a disc diaphragm.
words.name: Horn

words.def: A fore-and-aft structural member of the hull sloping up and backwards from the keel to support the counter.
words.name: Horn timber

words.def: 1.  Attachment of sheets to deck of vessel (main-sheet horse).
words.name: Horse

words.def: The electrical load for all non-propulsion systems on a ship.
words.name: Hotel load

words.def: Attachments of stays to masts.
words.name: Hounds

words.def: 1.  A ship, often an old ship or one that has become obsolete or uneconomical to operate, that has had its rigging or internal equipment removed and is incapable of going to sea, but that is afloat and continues to serve a useful function, such as providing living, office, training, storage, or prison space.
words.name: Hulk

words.def: The shell and framework of the basic flotation-oriented part of a ship.
words.name: Hull

words.def: Of a vessel when only its upper parts are visible over the horizon.
words.name: Hull-down

words.def: The maximum efficient speed of a displacement-hulled vessel.
words.name: Hull speed

words.def: A boat with wing-like foils mounted on struts below the hull, lifting the hull entirely out of the water at speed and allowing water resistance to be greatly reduced.
words.name: Hydrofoil

words.def: A special-purpose ship or boat designed to move and navigate through ice-covered waters.
words.name: Icebreaker

words.def: A serious hazard where cold temperatures (below about −10°C) combined with high wind speed (typically force 8 or above on the Beaufort scale) result in spray blown off the sea freezing immediately on contact with the ship
words.name: Icing

words.def: Members of a ship's company not required to serve watches. These were in general specialist tradesmen such as the carpenter and the sailmaker.
words.name: Idlers

words.def: Of a vessel: Having only ballast (q.v.) – and no cargo – as a load.
words.name: In ballast (or "in ballast condition")

words.def: When a sailing vessel has lost its forward momentum while heading into the wind, rendering it unable to steer.
words.name: In Irons

words.def: An 18th- and 19th-century term originally used to refer to a naval vessel out of service for repair or maintenance, later coming to mean naval ships in reserve with no more than a caretaker crew.
words.name: In ordinary

words.def: A method of surveying the underwater parts of a ship while it is still afloat instead of having to drydock it for examination of these areas as was conventionally done.
words.name: In-water Survey

words.def: In the vicinity of; in the area of.
words.name: In way of

words.def: 1.  Situated within a vessel.
words.name: Inboard

words.def: An engine mounted within the hull of a vessel, usually driving a fixed propeller by a shaft protruding through the stern. Generally used on larger vessels. See also sterndrive and outboard motor.
words.name: Inboard motor

words.def: See sterndrive.
words.name: Inboard-Outboard drive system

words.def: A type of clip for attaching a flag to a flag halyard.
words.name: Inglefield clip

words.def: 1.  Near (especially in sight of) or toward the shore.
words.name: Inshore

words.def: A slang term for autopilot.
words.name: Iron Mike

words.def: An auxiliary motor on a schooner.
words.name: Iron topsail

words.def: What sailors call inboard engines.
words.name: Iron wind

words.def: A steam-propelled warship protected by iron or steel armor plates of the period from 1859 until the 1890s (when the term "ironclad" fell out of use).
words.name: Ironclad

words.def: The superstructure of an aircraft carrier that extends above the flight deck. A carrier that lacks one is said to be flush-decked.
words.name: Island

words.def: 1.  A sailor. Also jack tar or just tar.
words.name: Jack

words.def: Sometimes spelled jackass bark, is a sailing ship with three (or more) masts, of which the foremast is square-rigged and the main is partially square-rigged (topsail, topgallant, etc.) and partially fore-and-aft rigged (course). The mizzen mast is fore-and-aft rigged.
words.name: Jackass-barque

words.def: A naval stores clerk.
words.name: Jack Dusty

words.def: A sailor dressed in 'square rig' with square collar. Formerly with a tarred pigtail.
words.name: Jack Tar

words.def: Lines, often steel wire with a plastic jacket, from the bow to the stern on both port and starboard. A crewmember clips his safety harness to a jackline, allowing him to walk along the deck while still being safely attached to the vessel.
words.name: Jacklines or jack stays

words.def: See genoa
words.name: Jenny

words.def: A man-made wall in open water rising several feet above high tide made of rubble and rocks used to create a breakwater, shelter, erosion control, a channel, or other such purpose.
words.name: Jetty

words.def: Debris ejected from a ship that sinks or washes ashore. See also Flotsam.
words.name: Jetsam

words.def: A triangular staysail at the front of a ship.
words.name: Jib

words.def: A spar used to extend the bowsprit.
words.name: Jibboom

words.def: See gybe.
words.name: Jibe

words.def: See gybe-oh.
words.name: Jibe-ho

words.def: The fourth mast, although ships with four or more masts were uncommon, or the aft most mast where it is smallest on vessels of less than four masts.
words.name: Jigger-mast

words.def: Traditional Royal Navy nickname for the Royal Marines.
words.name: Jollies

words.def: a slender triangular recess cut into the faying surface of a frame or steamed timber to fit over the land of clinker planking, or cut into the faying edge of a plank or rebate to avoid feather ends on a strake of planking. The feather end is cut off to produce a nib. The joggle and nib in this case is made wide enough to allow a caulking iron to enter the seam.
words.name: Joggle

words.def: A person (either a sailor or a passenger) who carries a jinx, one whose presence on board brings bad luck and endangers the ship.
words.name: Jonah

words.def: 1.  Old cordage past its useful service life as lines aboard ship. The strands of old junk were teased apart in the process called picking oakum.
words.name: Junk

words.def: Both the act of rigging a temporary mast and sails and the name of the resulting rig. A jury rig would be built at sea when the original rig was damaged, then it would be used to sail to a harbor or other safe place for permanent repairs.
words.name: Jury rig

words.def: a type of Proa native to Palau.[23]
words.name: Kaep

words.def: A technique for moving or turning a ship by using a relatively light anchor known as a kedge. The kedge anchor may be dropped while in motion to create a pivot and thus perform a sharp turn. The kedge anchor may also be carried away from the ship in a smaller boat, dropped, and then weighed, pulling the ship forward.
words.name: Kedge

words.def: The central structural basis of the hull.
words.name: Keel

words.def: Maritime punishment: to punish by dragging under the keel of a ship.
words.name: Keelhauling

words.def: See anchor sentinel.
words.name: Kellet

words.def: The timber immediately above the keel of a wooden ship.
words.name: Kelson

words.def: Weights (often scrap or pig iron) used as permanent high-density ballast.
words.name: Kentledge

words.def: A two-masted fore-and-aft rigged sailboat with the aft mast (the mizzen) mounted (stepped) afore (in front of) the rudder.
words.name: Ketch

words.def: A small anchor. A fouled killick is the substantive badge of non-commissioned officers in the RN. Seamen promoted to the first step in the promotion ladder are called 'Killick'. The badge signifies that here is an able seaman skilled to cope with the awkward job of dealing with a fouled anchor.
words.name: Killick

words.def: A rope, tackle or hydraulic ram running from the mast at or just above deck level to a point part-way along the boom of a yacht's mainsail or mizzen. Its function is to pull the boom down, flattening the sail in strong winds, reducing twist and preventing the boom from kicking up when running.
words.name: Kicking strap

words.def: The centerline plank of a laid deck. Its sides are often recessed, or nibbed, to take the ends of their parallel curved deck planks.
words.name: King plank

words.def: A valve, which can be opened from the inside of the ship, that connects the sea to internal fuel, water, or ballast tanks (see also seacock).
words.name: Kingston valve

words.def: Bending over the barrel of a gun for punitive beating with a cane or cat.
words.name: Kissing the gunner's daughter

words.def: Hinged cowling around a fixed propeller, allowing the drive to be directed to the side or forwards to manoeuvre the vessel.
words.name: Kitchen rudder

words.def: 1.  Connects two parts roughly at right angles, e.g. deck beams to frames.
words.name: Knee

words.def: 1.  A mitred backing timber which extends the after line of the rabbet in the stem to give extra support to the ends of the planks and the bowsprit.
words.name: Knighthead

words.def: See Header.
words.name: Knock

words.def: The condition of a sailboat being pushed abruptly to horizontal, with the mast parallel to the water surface.
words.name: Knockdown

words.def: A unit of speed: 1 nautical mile (1.8520 km; 1.1508 mi) per hour. Originally speed was measured by paying out a line from the stern of a moving boat; the line had a knot every 47 feet 3 inches (14.40 m), and the number of knots passed out in 30 seconds gave the speed through the water in nautical miles per hour. Sometimes "knots" is mistakenly stated as "knots per hour," but the latter is a measure of acceleration (i.e., "nautical miles per hour per hour") rather than of speed.
words.name: Knot

words.def: A sailor who 'knows the ropes' is familiar with the miles of cordage and ropes involved in running a ship.
words.name: Know the ropes

words.def: On board a ship, all "stairs" are called ladders, except for literal staircases aboard passenger ships. Most "stairs" on a ship are narrow and nearly vertical, hence the name. Believed to be from the Anglo-Saxon word hiaeder, meaning ladder.
words.name: Ladder

words.def: Debris that has sunk to the seabed.
words.name: Lagan

words.def: To be placed in reserve or mothballed. The latter usage is used in modern times and can refer to a specific set of procedures used by the US Navy to preserve ships in good condition.
words.name: Laid up

words.def: Great Lakes slang for a vessel which spends all her time on the five Great Lakes.
words.name: Laker

words.def: A person unfamiliar with being on the sea.
words.name: Land lubber

words.def: A rope that ties something off.
words.name: Lanyard

words.def: Obsolete term for the left side of a ship. Derived from "lay-board" providing access between a ship and a quay, when ships normally docked with the left side to the wharf. Replaced by port side or port, to avoid confusion with starboard.
words.name: Larboard

words.def: See By and large.
words.name: Large

words.def: A fore-and-aft triangular sail set on a long yard mounted at an angle to the mast.
words.name: Lateen sail or Latin-rig

words.def: A system of aids to navigation in which characteristics of buoys and beacons indicate the sides of the channel or route relative to a conventional direction of buoyage (usually upstream).
words.name: Lateral system

words.def: 1.  Traditionally, a launch was the largest ship's boat carried by a warship.
words.name: Launch

words.def: To come and go, used in giving orders to the crew, such as "lay forward" or "lay aloft". To direct the course of vessel. Also, to twist the strands of a rope together. To make it to a mark, buoy, or harbor, such as "We will lay the mark".
words.name: Lay

words.def: An unexpected delay time during a voyage often spent at anchor or in a harbor. It is usually caused by bad weather, equipment failure or needed maintenance.
words.name: Lay day

words.def: Laying the keel of a ship in a shipyard to begin her construction.
words.name: Laying down

words.def: 1.  A small stowage locker at the aft end of a boat.
words.name: Lazaret (also Lazarette or Lazaretto)

words.def: A network of cordage rigged to a point on the mast and to a series of points on either side of the boom that cradles and guides the sail onto the boom when the sail is lowered.
words.name: Lazy jacks, lazyjacks

words.def: 1.  A plummet or mass of lead attached to a line, used in sounding depth at sea.
words.name: Lead

words.def: An instrument used in navigation to measure water depth; the line attached to a lead.
words.name: Leadline (also sounding line)

words.def: A sailor who takes soundings with a lead, measuring the depth of water.
words.name: Leadsman

words.def: A unit of length, normally equal to three nautical miles.
words.name: League

words.def: The tendency of a sailboat to turn to leeward in a strong wind when there is no change in the rudder's position. This is the opposite of weather helm and is the result of a dynamically unbalanced condition. See also Center of lateral resistance.
words.name: Lee helm

words.def: The side of a ship sheltered from the wind (cf. weather side).
words.name: Lee side

words.def: A shore downwind of a ship. A ship which cannot sail well to windward risks being blown onto a lee shore and grounded.
words.name: Lee shore

words.def: A fin mounted on the side of a boat (usually in pairs) that can be lowered on the lee side of the ship to reduce leeway (similarly to a centerboard, which see).
words.name: Leeboard

words.def: The aft or trailing edge of a fore-and-aft sail; the leeward edge of a spinnaker; a vertical edge of a square sail. The leech is susceptible to twist, which is controlled by the boom vang, mainsheet and, if rigged with one, the gaff vang.
words.name: Leech

words.def: The command given to come about (tack through the wind) on a sailing boat.
words.name: Lee-oh or hard-a-lee

words.def: In the direction that the wind is blowing towards.
words.name: Leeward (/ˈluːərd/ in nautical use)

words.def: The amount that a ship is blown leeward by the wind. Also the amount of open free sailing space available to leeward before encountering hazards. See also weatherly.
words.name: Leeway

words.def: In navigation, a segment of a voyage between two waypoints.
words.name: Leg

words.def: The length of a vessel along the waterline from the forward surface of the stem, or main bow perpendicular member, to the after surface of the sternpost, or main stern perpendicular member. Believed to give a reasonable idea of the vessel's carrying capacity, as it excludes the small, often unusable volume contained in her overhanging ends.
words.name: Length between perpendiculars, also p/p, p.p., pp, LPP, LBP or Length BPP

words.def: The maximum length of a vessel's hull measured parallel to the waterline, usually measured on the hull alone, and including overhanging ends that extend beyond the main bow and main stern perpendicular members. For sailing vessels, this may exclude the bowsprit and other fittings added to the hull, but sometimes bowsprits are included.
words.name: Length overall, or LOA

words.def: An order indicating that the ship is now on the desired course relative to the wind and that the sails should be trimmed ('hauled') to suit.
words.name: Let go and haul

words.def: A warrant granted to a privateer condoning specific acts of piracy against a target as a redress for grievances.
words.name: Letter of marque and reprisal or just Letter of marque

words.def: A relatively short period when a sailor is allowed ashore for recreation. See also shore leave.
words.name: Liberty

words.def: To have the ship's sails arranged so as to counteract each other. A ship in this condition or in the process of achieving this condition is lying to.
words.name: Lie to

words.def: A device such as a buoyant ring or inflatable jacket which keeps a person afloat in the water.
words.name: Lifebelt, lifebuoy, lifejacket, life preserver, personal flotation device

words.def: 1.  Shipboard lifeboat, kept on board a vessel and used to take crew and passengers to safety in the event of the ship being abandoned.
words.name: Lifeboat

words.def: An inflatable, covered raft, used in the event of a vessel being abandoned.
words.name: Liferaft

words.def: An enabling wind shift that allows a close hauled sailboat to point up from its current course to a more favorable one. This is the opposite of a header.
words.name: Lift

words.def: A flat-bottomed barge used to transfer goods and passengers to and from moored ships, traditionally unpowered and moved and steered using "sweeps" (long oars), with their motive power provided by water currents.
words.name: Lighter

words.def: The process of transferring cargo from one vesel to another to reduce the draft of the first vessel. Done to allow a vessel to enter a port with limited depth or to help free a grounded vessel.
words.name: Lightering

words.def: A permanently anchored vessel performing the functions of a lighthouse, typically in a location where construction of the latter is impractical. These have largely been replaced by buoys or, as construction techniques have improved, actual lighthouses.
words.name: Lightvessel or lightship

words.def: The correct nautical term for the majority of the cordage or "ropes" used on a vessel. A line will always have a more specific name, such as mizzen topsail halyard, that specifies its use.
words.name: Line

words.def: In naval warfare, a line of battle formed behind a flagship
words.name: Line astern

words.def: 1.  During the Age of Sail, a ship-of-the-line, a major warship capable of taking its place in the main battleline of fighting ships.
words.name: Liner

words.def: A vessel's angle of lean or tilt to one side, in the direction called roll. Typically refers to a lean caused by flooding or improperly loaded or shifted cargo (as opposed to 'heeling', which see).
words.name: List

words.def: Literally, having cargo loaded as high as the ship's rail; also means extremely drunk.
words.name: Loaded to the gunwales

words.def: The technique used to convert a scaled drawing to full size used in boat construction.
words.name: Lofting

words.def: An iron ball attached to a long handle, used for driving caulking into seams and (occasionally) in a fight. Hence: 'at loggerheads'.
words.name: Loggerhead

words.def: The relative slackness of an anchor chain; this term means taut and extended.
words.name: Long stay

words.def: 1.  In the Age of Sail, a double-banked open boat carried by a sailing ship, rowed by eight or ten oarsmen, two per thwart, although designed also to be rigged for sailing; more seaworthy than a cutter or dinghy and with a beam greater than that of a gig. Eventually supplanted by the whaleboat.
words.name: Longboat

words.def: A type of ship invented and used by the Vikings for trade, commerce, exploration, and warfare, evolving over several centuries and appearing in its complete form between the 9th and 13th centuries.
words.name: Longship

words.def: A member of the crew specifically assigned to watch surrounding waters for other vessels, land, objects in the water, hazards, threats, etc. Lookouts usually have duty stations high on a vessel's superstructure or in her rigging in order to enhance their field of view.
words.name: Lookout

words.def: An irresponsible and reckless individual whose behavior (either intended or unintended) endangers the group he or she belongs to. A loose cannon, weighing thousands of pounds, would crush anything and anyone in its path, and possibly even break a hole in the hull, thus endangering the seaworthiness of the whole ship.
words.name: Loose cannon

words.def: A mainsail that is not connected to a boom along its foot.
words.name: Loose footed

words.def: 1.  The deck of a ship immediately above the hold.
words.name: Lower deck

words.def: A port cut into the bottom of the mizzentop (crow's-nest) allowing easy entry and exit. It was considered "un-seamanlike" to use this easier method rather than going over the side from the shrouds, and few sailors would risk the scorn of their shipmates by doing so (at least if there were witnesses).
words.name: Lubber's hole

words.def: A vertical line inside a compass case indicating the direction of the ship's head.
words.name: Lubber's line

words.def: The forward edge of a sail.
words.name: Luff

words.def: To bring the vessel so close to wind that the sails shake.[6]
words.name: Luff and touch her

words.def: To steer a sailing vessel more towards the direction of the wind until the pressure is eased on the [sheet].
words.name: Luff up

words.def: 1.  When a sailing vessel is steered far enough to windward that the sail is no longer completely filled with wind (the luff of a fore-and-aft sail begins to flap first).
words.name: Luffing

words.def: Waiting out a storm by dousing all sails and simply letting the boat drift.
words.name: Lying ahull

words.def: A Great Lakes ship designed to carry her own deck load of lumber and to tow one or two barges. The barges were big old schooners stripped of their masts and running gear to carry large cargoes of lumber.
words.name: Lumber hooker

words.def: A small sailing vessel with lugsails set on two or more masts and perhaps lug topsails, widely used as traditional fishing boats, particularly off the coasts of France, England and Scotland.
words.name: Lugger

words.def: A four-sided fore-and-aft sail supported by a spar along the top that is fixed to the mast at a point some distance from the center of the spar. See Lugger.
words.name: Lugsail

words.def: See Lie to.
words.name: Lying to

words.def: A Second World War personal flotation device used to keep people afloat in the water; named after the 1930s actress Mae West, well known for her large bosom.
words.name: Mae West

words.def: An absolute bearing (q.v.) using magnetic north.
words.name: Magnetic bearing

words.def: The direction towards the North Magnetic Pole. Varies slowly over time.
words.name: Magnetic north

words.def: The uppermost continuous deck extending from bow to stern.
words.name: Main deck

words.def: One of the braces attached to the mainmast.
words.name: Mainbrace

words.def: The tallest mast on a ship.
words.name: Mainmast (or Main)

words.def: Sail control line that allows the most obvious effect on mainsail trim. Primarily used to control the angle of the boom, and thereby the mainsail, this control can also increase or decrease downward tension on the boom while sailing upwind, significantly affecting sail shape. For more control over downward tension on the boom, use a boom vang.
words.name: Mainsheet

words.def: The stay running from the top of the mainmast to the bottom of the foremast, or from the top of the foremast to the ship's stem.
words.name: Mainstay

words.def: When a vessel is moving under its own power.
words.name: Making way

words.def: a warship from the Age of Sail
words.name: Man-of-war or man o' war

words.def: An emergency call that alerts the crew (q.v.) that someone aboard (q.v.) has gone overboard (q.v.) and must be rescued.
words.name: Man overboard!

words.def: To station the crew of a naval vessel along the rails and superstructure of the vessel as a method of saluting or rendering honors.
words.name: Man the rails

words.def: To have all of the crew of a sailing vessel not required on deck to handle the ship go aloft and spread out along the yards. Originally used in harbors to display the whole crew to the harbor authorities and the other ships present to show that the vessel's guns were not manned and hence her intentions were peaceful, manning the yards has since became a display used in harbor during celebrations and other special events.
words.name: Man the yards

words.def: A document listing the cargo, passengers, and crew of a ship for the use of customs and other officials.
words.name: Manifest

words.def: Another term for Bermudan rig. The mainsail is triangular, rigged fore-and-aft with the lead edge fixed to the mast. Refers to the similarity of the tall mast to a radio aerial.
words.name: Marconi rig

words.def: a docking facility for small ships and yachts.
words.name: Marina

words.def: 1.  A soldier trained for service afloat in a (primarily) infantry force that specializes in naval campaigns and subordinated to a navy or a separate naval branch of service rather than to an army. Often capitalized (e.g., "a Marine," or "the Marines"). Notable examples are the United Kingdom's Royal Marines, formed as the Duke of York and Albany's Maritime Regiment of Foot in 1664 with many and varied duties including providing guard to ship's officers should there be mutiny aboard, and the United States Marine Corps, formed in 1775 as a separate naval service alongside the United States Navy. It is incorrect, and often viewed by marines as offensive, to refer to a marine as a "soldier" or "infantryman," as these terms refer to personnel of an army rather than those of a marine force. It also is incorrect, and sometimes considered offensive by both merchant mariners and marines, to refer to merchant mariners (q.v.) as "merchant marines," because merchant mariners are civilian sailors responsible for operating merchant ships and are not marines. Marines sometimes are thought by seamen to be rather gullible, hence the phrase "tell it to the marines," meaning that one does not believe what is being said.
words.name: Marine

words.def: A sailor.
words.name: Mariner

words.def: 1.  Of or related to the sea (e.g., maritime activities, maritime law, maritime strategy).
words.name: Maritime

words.def: A tool used in ropework for tasks such as unlaying rope for splicing, untying knots, or forming a makeshift handle.
words.name: Marlinspike

words.def: A vertical pole on a ship which supports sails or rigging. If a wooden, multi-part mast, this term applies specifically to the lowest portion.
words.name: Mast

words.def: The process of raising the mast.
words.name: Mast stepping

words.def: A small platform partway up the mast, just above the height of the mast's main yard. A lookout is stationed here, and men who are working on the main yard will embark from here. See also crow's nest.
words.name: Masthead

words.def: 1.  The captain of a commercial vessel.
words.name: Master

words.def: A non-commissioned officer responsible for discipline on a naval ship. Standing between the officers and the crew, commonly known in the Royal Navy as 'the Buffer'.
words.name: Master-at-arms

words.def: A traditional Royal Navy term for an ordinary sailor.
words.name: Matelot

words.def: Military equipages of all descriptions for the naval services. The bombs, blankets, beans and bulletins of the Navy and Marine Corps. Taken from Nelson's British navy as the U.S. services became professional. Related: Materiel – the military equipages of the Army and Air Force, taken from Napoleon's French army as the U.S. services became professional.
words.name: Material

words.def: A collective term for all merchant ships registered in a given country and the civilians (especially those of that nationality) who man them; the ships and personnel in combination are said to constitute that country's merchant marine. Called the merchant navy in the United Kingdom and some other countries.
words.name: Merchant marine

words.def: A civilian officer or sailor who serves in the merchant marine (q.v.). Sometimes such personnel are incorrectly called "merchant marines," but both merchant mariners and marines frown on this term; although merchant mariners are part of the merchant marine, they are civilians and are not in any way marines (q.v.), which are a specialized type of military personnel .
words.name: Merchant mariner

words.def: A name bestowed upon the merchant marine (q.v.) of the United Kingdom by King George V, and since adopted by some other countries as well; the merchant navy's personnel are civilians, and the term "merchant navy" does not imply that they or their ships are a part of the navy. Synonymous with the term merchant marine.
words.name: Merchant navy

words.def: Any non-naval passenger- or cargo-carrying vessel, including cargo ships, tankers, and passenger ships but excluding troopships.
words.name: Merchantman

words.def: 1.  An eating place aboard ship.
words.name: Mess or messdeck

words.def: A system of catering in which a standard ration is issued to a mess supplemented by a money allowance which may be used by the mess to buy additional victuals from the pusser's stores or elsewhere. Each mess was autonomous and self-regulating. Seaman cooks, often members of the mess, prepared the meals and took them, in a tin canteen, to the galley to be cooked by the ship's cooks. As distinct from "cafeteria messing" where food is issued to the individual hand, which now the general practice.
words.name: Mess deck catering

words.def: The midway point between a vessel's center of buoyancy when upright and her center of buoyancy when tilted.
words.name: Metacenter

words.def: A measurement of the initial static stability of a vessel afloat, calculated as the distance between her centre of gravity and her metacenter. A vessel with a large metacentric height rolls more quickly and therefore more uncomfortably for people on board; a vessel with a small metacentric height will roll sluggishly and may face a greater danger of capsizing.
words.name: Metacentric height (also GM)

words.def: The middle section of a vessel with reference to the longitudinal plane, as distinguished from fore or aft. (Compare Amidships.)
words.name: Midships

words.def: 1.  During the 17th century, a naval rating for an experienced seaman.
words.name: Midshipman

words.def: An alternative to the Blackwall hitch, preferred if the rope is greasy. Made by first forming a Blackwall hitch and then taking the underneath part and placing over the bill of the hook.[24]
words.name: Midshipman's hitch

words.def: Broken pieces of biscuit as dessert.[25]
words.name: Midshipman's nuts

words.def: A slovenly method of rolling up a hammock transversely, and lashing it endways by one clue.[25]
words.name: Midshipman's roll

words.def: see nautical mile.
words.name: Mile

words.def: Hollow tubular masts used in warships in the last third of the 19th century, often equipped with a fighting top armed with light-caliber guns.
words.name: Military mast

words.def: A self-contained explosive device intended to damage or sink surface ships or submarines, designed to be placed in water and left to wait until they are triggered by the approach of, or contact with, a surface ship or submarines.
words.name: Mine

words.def: A sail on a ketch or yawl, usually lightweight, set from, and forward of, the mizzen mast while reaching in light to moderate air.
words.name: Mizzen staysail

words.def: The third mast, or mast aft of the mainmast, on a ship.
words.name: Mizzenmast (or Mizzen)

words.def: A massive structure, usually of stone or concrete, used as a pier, a breakwater, or a causeway between places separated by water. May have a wooden structure built upon it and resemble a wooden pier or wharf, but a mole differs from a pier, quay, or wharf in that water cannot flow freely underneath it.
words.name: Mole

words.def: 1.  A turreted ironclad warship of the second half of the 19th century characterized by low freeboard, shallow draft, poor seaworthiness, and heavy guns, intended for riverine and coastal operations.
words.name: Monitor

words.def: A high platform above the wheelhouse offering better visibility to the operator while maneuvering.
words.name: Monkey bridge

words.def: a ball woven out of line used to provide heft to heave the line to another location. The monkey fist and other heaving-line knots were sometimes weighted with lead (easily available in the form of foil used to seal e.g. tea chests from dampness) although Clifford W. Ashley notes that there was a "definite sporting limit" to the weight thus added.
words.name: Monkey's fist

words.def: 1.  To attach a boat to a mooring buoy or post.
words.name: Moor

words.def: A place to moor a vessel.
words.name: Mooring, also Moorings

words.def: A vessel which leads, serves, or carries smaller vessels, in the latter case either releasing them and then proceeding independently or also recovering them after they have completed a mission or operation. A mother ship sometimes contrasts with a tender (q.v.), which often (but not necessarily) is a vessel that supports or cares for larger vessels.
words.name: Mother ship (also mothership and mother-ship)

words.def: A template of the shape of the hull in transverse section. Several moulds are used to form a temporary framework around which a hull is built.
words.name: Mould

words.def: A cargo ship that has fittings to carry standard shipping containers and retractable tweendecks that can be moved out of the way so that the ship can carry bulk cargo.
words.name: Multipurpose vessel

words.def: The location on a vessel a person goes either during an emergency or a drill to prepare for one. i.e. A Muster Drill. If a person is believed missing, all hands would report to their muster station for a head count.
words.name: Muster Station

words.def: Prefix for "Motor Vessel", used before a ship's name.
words.name: M.V. (or MV)

words.def: Prefix for "Motor yacht", used before a yacht's name.
words.name: M.Y. (or MY)

words.def: A narrow part of a navigable waterway.
words.name: Narrows

words.def: A unit of length corresponding approximately to one minute of arc of latitude along any meridian arc. By international agreement it is exactly 1,852 metres (approximately 6,076 feet).
words.name: Nautical mile

words.def: The British system of authorizing naval construction by an annual bill in Parliament.
words.name: Naval Programme

words.def: 1.  Sailors subordinated to a navy trained and equipped to operate ashore temporarily as an organized infantry force, but at other times responsible for the normal duties of sailors aboard ship.
words.name: Naval infantry

words.def: Rules of the road that provide guidance on how to avoid collision and also used to assign blame when a collision does occur.
words.name: Navigation rules

words.def: "no"; the opposite of "aye".
words.name: Nay

words.def: Short rope used to bind a cable to the "messenger" (a moving line propelled by the capstan) so that the cable is dragged along too (used where the cable is too large to be wrapped round the capstan itself). During the raising of an anchor the nippers were attached and detached from the (endless) messenger by the ship's boys. Hence the term for small boys: "nippers".
words.name: Nipper

words.def: The entire ship's company was expected to witness floggings, assembled on deck. If it was very crowded, the bosun might not have room to swing the "cat o' nine tails" (the whip).
words.name: No room to swing a cat

words.def: See Self-sustaining.
words.name: Non-self-sustaining

words.def: A type of navigational buoy often cone shaped, but if not, always triangular in silhouette, colored green in IALA region A or red in IALA region B (the Americas, Japan, Korea and the Philippines). In channel marking its use is opposite that of a "can buoy".
words.name: Nun

words.def: Material used for caulking hulls. Often hemp picked from old untwisted ropes.
words.name: Oakum

words.def: See Liner.
words.name: Ocean liner

words.def: the more distant part of the sea as seen from the shore and generally beyond anchoring ground.
words.name: Offing

words.def: 1.  Moving away from the shore.
words.name: Offshore

words.def: 1.  A naval auxiliary ship with fuel tanks and dry cargo holds designed to replenish other ships with fuel and supplies while underway on the high seas. See Oiler (ship).
words.name: Oiler

words.def: Foul-weather clothing worn by sailors.
words.name: Oilskins or oilies

words.def: Crew's slang for the captain (master or commanding officer) of a vessel.
words.name: Old man, (The)

words.def: Slang for an experienced mariner.
words.name: Old salt

words.def: See "aboard".
words.name: On board (sometimes "onboard")

words.def: A ship's destination, typically an area to be patrolled or guarded.
words.name: On station

words.def: A boat that has been hauled and is now sitting on dry land.
words.name: On the hard

words.def: An organization that will register merchant ships owned by foreign entities, generally to provide a flag of convenience (q.v.).
words.name: Open registry

words.def: See in ordinary.
words.name: Ordinary

words.def: Great Lakes term for a vessel primarily used in the transport of iron ore.
words.name: Oreboat

words.def: The lowest deck of a ship of the line. The deck covering in the hold.
words.name: Orlop deck

words.def: 1.  Situated outside the hull of a vessel.
words.name: Outboard

words.def: A motor mounted externally on the transom of a small boat. The boat may be steered by twisting the whole motor, instead of or in addition to using a rudder.
words.name: Outboard motor

words.def: The lower part of a sterndrive (q.v.).
words.name: Outdrive

words.def: A line used to control the shape of a sail.
words.name: Outhaul

words.def: To leave the safety of port, heading for the open ocean.
words.name: Outward bound

words.def: To have too great a sail area up to safely maneuver in the current wind conditions.
words.name: Over-canvassed

words.def: When tacking, holding a course too long.
words.name: Over-reaching

words.def: Adult sailors were flogged on the back or shoulders while tied to a grating, but boys were beaten instead on the posterior (often bared), with a cane or cat, while bending, often tied down, over the barrel of a gun, known as Kissing the gunner's daughter.
words.name: Over the barrel

words.def: To sail downwind directly at another ship, stealing the wind from its sails.
words.name: Overbear

words.def: Off or outside a vessel. If something or someone falls, jumps, or is thrown off of a vessel into the water, the object or person is said to have gone overboard. See "Man overboard!"
words.name: Overboard

words.def: Dangerously steep and breaking seas due to opposing currents and wind in a shallow area, or strong currents over a shallow rocky bottom.
words.name: Overfalls

words.def: The ceiling of any enclosed space below decks in a vessel, essentially the bottom of the deck above you.
words.name: Overhead

words.def: Hauling the buntline ropes over the sails to prevent them from chafing.
words.name: Overhaul

words.def: Capsized or foundered.
words.name: Overwhelmed

words.def: traditional Royal Navy term for the Captain, a survival from the days when privately owned ships were often hired for naval service.
words.name: Owner

words.def: A cloud or other weather phenomenon that may be indicative of an upcoming storm.
words.name: Ox-eye

words.def: 1.  Originally, a vessel employed to carry post office mail packets to and from British embassies, colonies and outposts.
words.name: Packet, Packet boat, or packet ship

words.def: Any regularly scheduled cargo, passenger and mail trade conducted by ship.
words.name: Packet trade

words.def: A seaman aboard a ship engaged in packet trade.
words.name: Packetman

words.def: A rope attached to the bow of a dinghy, usually used to tow dingy or handle it at dockside, or in water.
words.name: Painter

words.def: The pulsation in and out of the bow and stern plating as the ship alternately rises and plunges deep into the water
words.name: Panting

words.def: A method of lifting a roughly cylindrical object such as a spar. One end of a rope is made fast above the object, a loop of rope is lowered and passed around the object, which can be raised by hauling on the free end of rope.
words.name: Parbuckle

words.def: a discussion or conference, especially between enemies, over terms of a truce or other matters.
words.name: Parley

words.def: A movable loop or collar, used to fasten a yard or gaff to its respective mast. Parrel still allows the spar to be raised or lowered and swivel around the mast. Can be made of wire or rope and fitted with beads to reduce friction.
words.name: Parrel

words.def: Fall out with a friend. From the days when cleaning materials were shared between sailors.
words.name: Part brass rags

words.def: Hallway of a ship.
words.name: Passageway

words.def: A merchant ship configured primarily for the transportation of cargo but also for the transportation of at least some passengers.
words.name: Passenger-cargoman

words.def: To let a vessel's head fall off from the wind (to leeward.)
words.name: Pay off

words.def: Filling a seam (with caulking or pitch), lubricating the running rigging; paying with slush (q.v.), protecting from the weather by covering with slush. See also: the devil to pay. (French from paix, pitch)
words.name: Paying

words.def: The officer responsible for all money matters in RN ships including the paying and provisioning of the crew, all stores, tools and spare parts. See also: purser.
words.name: Paymaster

words.def: 1.  The upper aftermost corner of a fore-and-aft sail; used in many combinations, such as peak-halyards, peak-brails, etc.
words.name: Peak

words.def: 1.  Living in the open ocean rather than coastal or inland waters, (e.g., " a pelagic shark").
words.name: Pelagic

words.def: A length of wire or rope secured at one end to a mast or spar and having a block or other fitting at the lower end. Often used incorrectly when referring to a Pennant (flag).
words.name: Pendant

words.def: A long, thin triangular flag flown from the masthead of a military ship (as opposed to a burgee, the flags thus flown on yachts).
words.name: Pennant

words.def: A boat on sentry duty, or one placed on a line forward of a position to warn against an enemy advance.
words.name: Picket boat

words.def: A raised structure, typically supported by widely spread piles or pillars, used industrially for loading and unloading commercial ships, receationally for walking and housing attractions at a seaside resort, or as a structure for use by boatless fishermen. The lighter structure of a pier contrasts with the more solid foundations of a quay or the closely spaced piles of a wharf. In North America, the term "pier" used alone connotes either a pier used (or formerly used) by commercial shipping or one used for fishing, while in Europe the term used alone connotes a recreational pier at a seaside resort.
words.name: Pier

words.def: When a sailor is drafted to a warship at the last minute, just before she sails.
words.name: Pier-head jump

words.def: Navigator. A specially knowledgeable person qualified to navigate a vessel through difficult waters, e.g. harbour pilot etc.
words.name: Pilot

words.def: Points (or plan) of intended movement. The charted course for a naval unit's movements.
words.name: PIM

words.def: 1.  Pinnace (ship's boat), a small, light boat propelled by oars or a sail, used as a tender to larger vessels during the Age of Sail.
words.name: Pinnace

words.def: The pin or bolt on which a ship's rudder pivots. The pintle rests in the gudgeon.
words.name: Pintle

words.def: A whistle used by Boatswains (bosuns or bos'ns) to issue commands. Consisting of a metal tube which directs the breath over an aperture on the top of a hollow ball to produce high pitched notes. The pitch of the notes can be changed by partly covering the aperture with the finger of the hand in which the pipe is held. The shape of the instrument is similar to that of a smoking pipe.
words.name: Pipe (Bos'n's), or a bos'n's call

words.def: A signal on the bosun's pipe to signal the end of the day, requiring lights (and smoking pipes) to be extinguished and silence from the crew.
words.name: Pipe down

words.def: A salute on the bos'n's pipe(s) performed in the company of the deck watch on the starboard side of the quarterdeck or at the head of the gangway, to welcome or bid farewell to the ship's Captain, senior officers and honoured visitors.
words.name: Piping the side

words.def: An act of robbery or criminal violence at sea by the occupants of one vessel against the occupants of another vessel (thus excluding such acts committed by the crew or passengers of a vessel against others aboard the same vessel). Piracy is distinguished from privateering, which is authorized by national authorities and therefore a legitimate form of war-like activity by non-state actors.
words.name: Piracy

words.def: One who engages in an act of piracy.
words.name: Pirate

words.def: A vessel's motion, rotating about the beam/transverse axis, causing the fore and aft ends to rise and fall repetitively.
words.name: Pitch

words.def: To capsize a boat stern over bow, rather than by rolling over.
words.name: Pitchpole

words.def: To skim over the water at high speed rather than push through it.
words.name: Plane

words.def: A special marking, positioned amidships, that indicates the draft of the vessel and the legal limit to which the vessel may be loaded for specific water types and temperatures.
words.name: Plimsoll line (also national Load Line)

words.def: see transmitting station.
words.name: Plotting room

words.def: A unit of bearing equal to one thirty-second of a circle, i.e., 11.25°. A turn of 32 points is a complete turn through 360°.
words.name: Point

words.def: To change the direction of a sailboat so that it is more up wind. To bring the bow windward. Also called heading up. This is the opposite of falling off.
words.name: Point up

words.def: The course of a sailing vessel in relation to the direction of the wind, divided into six points: in irons (pointed directly into the wind), close hauled (sailing as close into the direction of the wind as possible), close reach (between close hauled and beam reach), beam reach (perpendicular to the wind), broad reach (wind behind the vessel at an angle), and running downwind or running before the wind (the wind is behind the vessel).
words.name: Points of sail

words.def: A flat-bottomed vessel used as a ferry, barge, or car float, or a float moored alongside a jetty or a ship to facilitate boarding.
words.name: Pontoon

words.def: A high deck on the aft superstructure of a ship.
words.name: Poop deck

words.def: 1.  Swamped by a high, following sea.
words.name: Pooped

words.def: The left side of the boat. Towards the left-hand side of the ship facing forward (formerly Larboard). Denoted with a red light at night.
words.name: Port

words.def: The port listed in a vessel's registration documents and lettered on her stern. Often used incorrectly as a synonym for "home port", meaning the port at which the vessel is based, but which may differ from her port of registry.
words.name: Port of registry

words.def: When sailing with the wind coming from the port side of the vessel. Must give way to boats on starboard tack.
words.name: Port tack

words.def: an opening in a ship's side, esp. a round one for admitting light and air, fitted with thick glass and, often, a hinged metal cover, a window
words.name: Porthole or port

words.def: an obsolete alternative form of the rank of captain in the Royal Navy; once achieved promotion thereafter was entirely due to seniority.
words.name: Post-captain

words.def: A hulk used to store gunpowder.
words.name: Powder hulk

words.def: A small room/closet area in the hull of the ship used for storing gunpowder in barrels, or, "kegs", usually located centrally so as to have easy access to the grated loading area. Sometimes may be an enclosed closet with a door, so it can be locked and only the captain would have the key, similar to how rum is stored.
words.name: Powder magazine

words.def: Term used retrospectively after 1906 for a wide variety of steam battleships built between the 1880s and c. 1905 designed with only a few large guns for long-range fire, relying on an intermediate secondary battery used at shorter ranges for most of their offensive power, and having triple-expansion steam engines. They were rendered obsolete by the revolutionary dreadnought battleships which began to appear in 1906 and which differed from predreadnoughts in having steam turbine propulsion and an "all-big-gun" armament layout in which the ship's primary gun power resided in a primary battery of its largest guns intended for use at long range, with other gun armament limited to small weapons intended for defense against torpedo boats and other small warships.
words.name: Predreadnought

words.def: Formed body of personnel from a ship of the Royal Navy (either a ship seeking personnel for its own crew or from a 'press tender' seeking men for a number of ships) that would identify and force (press) men, usually merchant sailors into service on naval ships usually against their will.
words.name: Press gang

words.def: A sail control line originating at some point on the boom leading to a fixed point on the boat's deck or rail (usually a cleat or pad eye) used to prevent or moderate the effects of an accidental jibe.
words.name: Preventer (gybe preventer, jibe preventer)

words.def: PWO, one of a number of Warfare branch specialist officers.
words.name: Principal Warfare Officer

words.def: A vessel used as a prison, often to hold convicts awaiting transportation to penal colonies; particularly common in the British Empire in the 18th and 19th centuries.
words.name: Prison ship or prison hulk

words.def: In British usage, a commissioned warship in active service that is not being used as the flagship of a flag officer. The term does not imply in any way that the ship is privately owned.
words.name: Private ship

words.def: A privately owned ship authorised by a national power (by means of a #Letter of marque) to conduct hostilities against an enemy. Also called a private man of war.
words.name: Privateer

words.def: A property captured at sea in virtue of the rights of war, as a vessel.
words.name: Prize

words.def: Members of a warship's crew assigned to man a vessel taken as a prize.
words.name: Prize crew

words.def: A propeller mounted on a rigid shaft protruding from the hull of a vessel, usually driven by an inboard motor;
words.name: Propeller (fixed)

words.def: A propeller with folding blades, furling to reduce drag on a sailing vessel when not in use.
words.name: Propeller (folding)

words.def: tendency for a propeller to push the stern sideways. In theory a right hand propeller in reverse will walk the stern to port.
words.name: Propeller walk or prop walk

words.def: a poetical alternative term for bows.
words.name: Prow

words.def: Fibres of old rope packed between spars, or used as a fender.
words.name: Puddening

words.def: A mechanical method of increasing force, such as a tackle or lever.
words.name: Purchase

words.def: The person who buys, stores and sells all stores on board ships, including victuals, rum and tobacco. Originally a private merchant, latterly a warrant officer.
words.name: Purser

words.def: The aftermost deck of a warship. In the age of sail, the quarterdeck was the preserve of the ship's officers.
words.name: Quarterdeck

words.def: The standing orders governing the British Royal Navy issued in the name of the current Monarch.
words.name: Queen's (King's) Regulations

words.def: 1.  A stone or concrete structure on navigable water used for loading and unloading vessels, generally synonymous with a wharf (q.v.), although the solid foundations of a quay contrast with the closely spaced piles of a wharf. When "quay" and "wharf" are used as synonyms, the term "quay" is more common in everyday speech in the United Kingdom, many Commonwealth countries, and the Republic of Ireland, while "wharf" is more commonly used in the United States.
words.name: Quay

words.def: 1.  An area alongside a quay.
words.name: Quayside

words.def: A groove cut in wood to form part of a joint.
words.name: Rabbet or rebate /ˈræbət/

words.def: Acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging. An electronic system designed to transmit radio signals and receive reflected images of those signals from a "target" in order to determine the bearing and distance to the "target".
words.name: Radar

words.def: A special fixture fitted to a vessel or incorporated into the design of certain aids to navigation to enhance their ability to reflect radar energy. In general, these fixtures will materially improve the visibility for use by vessels with radar.
words.name: Radar reflector

words.def: To incline from the perpendicular; something so inclined is raked or raking, e.g., a raked or raking stem, stern, mast, funnel, etc.
words.name: Rake

words.def: 1.  A weapon consisting of an underwater prolongation of the bow of a vessel to form an armored beak, intended to be driven into the hull of an enemy vessel in order to puncture the hull and disable or sink that vessel.
words.name: Ram

words.def: A clockwork device used aboard a warship to continuously calculate the range to an enemy ship.
words.name: Range clock

words.def: Two lights associated to form a range (a line formed by the extension of a line connecting two charted points) which often, but not necessarily, indicates the channel centerline. The front range light is the lower of the two, and nearer to the mariner using the range. The rear light is higher and further from the mariner.
words.name: Range lights

words.def: 1.  In British usage, an enlisted member of a country's navy, i.e., all members of the navy who are not officers or warrant officers.
words.name: Rating

words.def: 1.  A sailing ship that has been cut down to reduce the number of decks.
words.name: Razee

words.def: Sailing across the wind: from about 60° to about 160° off the wind. Reaching consists of "close reaching" (about 60° to 80°), "beam reaching" (about 90°) and "broad reaching" (about 120° to 160°). See also beating and running.
words.name: Reaching

words.def: A specifically designed sail for tighter reaching legs. Reaching sails are often used in racing with a true wind angle of 35 to 95 degrees. They are generally used before the wind angle moves aft enough to permit spinnakers to be flown.
words.name: Reaching Sail

words.def: A call to indicate imminent tacking (see going about).
words.name: Ready about

words.def: A government official whose duty is to give owners of shipwrecks the opportunity to retrieve their property and ensure that law-abiding finders of wreck receive an appropriate reward.
words.name: Receiver of Wreck

words.def: A hulk used in harbor to house newly recruited sailors before they are assigned to a crew.
words.name: Receiving hulk or receiving ship

words.def: Traditional nickname for the Red Ensign, the civil ensign (flag) carried by United Kingdom civilian vessels.
words.name: Red Duster
