words.def: A passage of two vessels moving in the opposite direction on their port sides, so called because the red navigation light on one of the vessels faces the red light on the other vessel.
words.name: Red-to-red

words.def: A light version on the cat o'nine tails for use on boys; also called "boys' pussy".
words.name: Reduced cat

words.def: 1.  Reefing: To temporarily reduce the area of a sail exposed to the wind, usually to guard against adverse effects of strong wind or to slow the vessel.
words.name: Reef

words.def: Small flat lengths of braided cord attached by eyelets to a sail along the reef band, used to secure the excess fabric after reefing. Typically, a reef point consists of two lengths of cord which taper towards their ends—the narrow end of each is threaded through an eye in the wide end of the other and then the pair are rove through the eyelet in the reef band such that one length hangs before and the other abaft the sail.[26]
words.name: Reef-points

words.def: Long pieces of rough canvas sewed across the sails to give them additional strength.
words.name: Reef-bands

words.def: Ropes employed in the operation of reefing.
words.name: Reef-tackles

words.def: 1.  A shipboard refrigerator.
words.name: Reefer

words.def: (Past tense rove) To thread a line through blocks in order to gain a mechanical advantage, such as in a block and tackle.
words.name: Reeve

words.def: A series of boat races, usually of sailboats or rowboats, but occasionally of powered boats.
words.name: Regatta

words.def: A bearing relative to the direction of the ship: the clockwise angle between the ship's direction and an object. See also absolute bearing and bearing.
words.name: Relative bearing

words.def: A ship designed and equipped to carry out research at sea, especially hydrographic survey, oceanographic research, fisheries research, naval research, polar research, and oil exploration.
words.name: Research vessel

words.def: The system of masts and lines on ships and other sailing vessels.
words.name: Rigging

words.def: The force which tends to restore a ship to equilibrium once a heel has altered the relationship between her centre of buoyancy and her centre of gravity.
words.name: Righting couple

words.def: The rim or 'eyebrow' above a port-hole or scuttle.
words.name: Rigol

words.def: A man-made pile of rocks and rubble often surrounding an off-shore lighthouse or as a base for an aid to navigation.
words.name: Rip rap

words.def: See roadstead.
words.name: Roads

words.def: A sheltered area outside a harbour where a ship can lie safe at anchor, also known as a roads.
words.name: Roadstead

words.def: The anchor line, rope or cable connecting the anchor chain to the vessel. Also Anchor Rode.
words.name: Rode

words.def: A surprisingly large wave for a given sea state; formally, a wave whose height is more than twice the significant wave height (i.e., the mean of the largest third of waves in a wave record).
words.name: Rogue wave

words.def: A vessel's motion rotating from side to side, about the fore-aft/longitudinal axis. Listing is a lasting, stable tilt, or heel, along the longitudinal axis. Roll is also an alternate name for the longitudinal axis (roll axis).
words.name: Roll

words.def: A vessel designed to carry wheeled cargo that can drive on and off the ship on its own wheels.
words.name: Roll-on/roll-off ship (also RORO or ro-ro)

words.def: A number of pulleys, engaged to confine the yard to the weather side of the mast; this tackle is much used in a rough sea.
words.name: Rolling-tackle

words.def: In a convoy, a ship that breaks ranks and "romps" ahead.
words.name: Romper

words.def: the lines in the rigging.
words.name: Ropes, the

words.def: A summary punishment device.
words.name: Rope's end

words.def: 1.  A period, traditionally on Wednesday afternoons, when a tailor boarded a sailing warship while the vessel was in port; the crew was excused from most duties and had light duty mending uniforms and hammocks and darning socks. When the ship was at sea, the crew similarly was excused from most duties on Wednesday afternoons to engage in mending chores. Wednesday afternoons, like Sundays, thus were a more social time which allowed crewmen a rest from their normal duties, similar to a Sunday, and, because the crew used rope yarn for mending, Wednesday afternoon became known as rope yarn Sunday.
words.name: Rope yarn

words.def: See roll-on/roll-off ship.
words.name: RORO or ro-ro

words.def: A bracket providing the fulcrum for an oar. See also thole.
words.name: Rowlock /ˈrɒlək/

words.def: 1.  In large sailing ships, a mast right above the topgallant mast.
words.name: Royal

words.def: An extra plank fitted to the outside of the hull, usually at deck level, to protect the topsides.
words.name: Rubbing strake

words.def: A steering device which can be placed aft, externally relative to the keel or compounded into the keel either independently or as part of the bulb/centerboard.
words.name: Rudder

words.def: see go-fast boat.
words.name: Rum-runner

words.def: 1.  A place or room for the stowage of cargo in a vessel.
words.name: Rummage (obsolete spelling "romage")

words.def: A sale of damaged cargo (from French arrimage).
words.name: Rummage sale

words.def: 1.  The stern of the underwater body of a ship from where it begins to curve upward and inward.
words.name: Run

words.def: Sailing more than about 160° away from the wind. If directly away from the wind, it's a dead run.
words.name: Running before the wind or running

words.def: The propellers, shafts, struts and related parts of a motorboat.
words.name: Running gear

words.def: Rigging used to manipulate sails, spars, etc. in order to control the movement of the ship. Cf. standing rigging.
words.name: Running rigging

words.def: A harbour which provides safety from bad weather
words.name: Safe harbour

words.def: A safe harbour, including natural harbours, which provide safety from bad weather or attack.
words.name: Safe haven

words.def: When the trough of a wave is amidships, causing the hull to deflect so the ends of the keel are higher than the middle. The opposite of hogging.
words.name: Sagging

words.def: 1.  A piece of fabric attached to a vessel and arranged such that it causes the wind to drive the vessel along. It may be attached to the vessel via a combination of mast, spars, and ropes.
words.name: Sail

words.def: A large open space used by sailmakers to spread out sails.
words.name: Sail loft

words.def: A set of drawings showing various sail combinations recommended for use in various situations.
words.name: Sail-plan

words.def: see 'skiff'.
words.name: Sailing skiff

words.def: A craftsman who makes and repairs sails, working either on shore in a sail loft or aboard a large, ocean-going sailing ship.
words.name: Sailmaker

words.def: A method of freeing a vessel grounded on mud in which the crew forms a line and runs back and forth athwartships (q.v.) to cause her to rock back and forth, breaking the mud's suction and freeing her with little or no hull damage. When this is required, the crew is given the order Sally ship!
words.name: Sally ship

words.def: Great Lakes term for a vessel that sails the oceans.
words.name: Saltie

words.def: Slang for a sailor, especially for a seaman in the navy.
words.name: Salty dog

words.def: A person engaged in salvage of a ship or items lost at sea.
words.name: Salvor

words.def: A relatively flat bottomed Chinese wooden boat from 3.5 to 4.5 m long; some with a small shelter and may be used as permanent habitation on inland waters; generally used in coastal areas or rivers and as traditional fishing boats. It is unusual for a sampan to sail far from land as they do not have the means to survive rough weather.
words.name: Sampan

words.def: A strong vertical post used to support a ship's windlass and the heel of a ship's bowsprit.
words.name: Sampson post

words.def: To reduce the area and efficiency of a sail by expedient means (slacking the peak and tricing up the tack) without properly reefing, thus slowing boat speed. Also used in the past as a sign of mourning.
words.name: Scandalize

words.def: Dimensions of ships structural members, e.g., frame, beam, girder, etc.
words.name: Scantlings

words.def: A type of sailing vessel characterized by the use of fore-and-aft sails on two or more masts with the forward mast being no taller than the rear masts, first used by the Dutch in the 16th or 17th century.
words.name: Schooner

words.def: 1.  A method of preparing an anchor for tripping by attaching an anchor cable to the crown and fixing to the ring by a light seizing (also known as becue). The seizing can be broken if the anchor becomes fouled.
words.name: Scow

words.def: This is a specialty sail whose name comes from combining the names spinnaker and Reaching sails and can be used as an upwind genoa sail, reaching sail, or downwind sail.
words.name: Screecher

words.def: 1.  Propeller.
words.name: Screw

words.def: A name given by sailors to the lowest clouds, which are mostly observed in squally weather.
words.name: Scud

words.def: A term applied to a vessel when carried furiously along by a tempest.
words.name: Scudding

words.def: 1.  An oar used for sculling.
words.name: Scull

words.def: A method of using oars to propel watercraft in which the oar or oars touch the water on both the port and starboard sides of the craft, or over the stern. On sailboats with transom-mounted rudders, forward propulsion can be made by a balanced side to side movement of the tiller, a form of sculling.
words.name: Sculling

words.def: Originally a series of pipes fitted through the ship's side from inside the thicker deck waterway to the topside planking to drain water overboard, larger quantities drained through freeing ports, which were openings in the bulwarks.
words.name: Scuppers

words.def: A small opening, or lid thereof, in a ship's deck or hull.
words.name: Scuttle

words.def: 1.  A barrel with a hole in used to hold water that sailors would drink from. By extension (in modern naval usage), a shipboard drinking fountain or water cooler.
words.name: Scuttlebutt

words.def: Making a hole in the hull of a vessel or opening seacocks, especially in order to sink a vessel deliberately.
words.name: Scuttling

words.def: A stabilizer deployed in the water for heaving to in heavy weather. It acts as a brake and keeps the hull in line with the wind and perpendicular to waves. Often in the form of a large bag made of heavy canvas. See also drogue.
words.name: Sea anchor

words.def: A watertight box built against the hull of the ship communicating with the sea through a grillage, to which valves and piping are attached to allow water in for ballast, engine cooling, and firefighting purposes. Also a wooden box used to store a sailor's effects.
words.name: Sea chest

words.def: The general condition of the free surface on a large body of water with respect to wind waves and swell at a certain location and moment, characterized by statistics, including the wave height, period, and power spectrum. The sea state varies with time, as the wind conditions or swell conditions change.
words.name: Sea state

words.def: The testing phase of a boat, ship, or submarine, usually the final step in her construction, conducted to measure a vessel's performance and general seaworthiness before her owners take delivery of her.
words.name: Sea trial

words.def: High waterproof boots for use at sea. In leisure sailing, known as sailing wellies.
words.name: Seaboots

words.def: a valve in the hull of a boat.
words.name: Seacock

words.def: The hunting of seals.
words.name: Sealing

words.def: Generic term for sailor, or (part of) a low naval rank
words.name: Seaman

words.def: Certified for, and capable of, safely sailing at sea.
words.name: Seaworthy

words.def: Also called second officer, a licensed member of the deck department of a merchant ship, third – or on some ocean liners fourth – in command; a watchkeeping officer, customarily the ship's navigator. Other duties vary, but the second mate is often the medical officer and in charge of maintaining distress signaling equipment. On oil tankers, the second mate usually assists the chief mate with tank-cleaning operations.
words.name: Second mate

words.def: See second mate.
words.name: Second officer

words.def: A merchant ship which is able to unload herself without any assistance from a harbor's facilities is self-sustaining, while a ship which requires the assistance of a harbor's facilities to unload herself is non-self-sustaining. Self-sustaining ships are more expensive to build, maintain, and operate than non-self-sustaining ships, but have the advantage of being able to operate in less-developed ports that lack the infrastructure necessary to unload ships.
words.name: Self-sustaining

words.def: Great Lakes slang term for a vessel with a conveyor or some other method of unloading the cargo without shoreside equipment.
words.name: Self-unloader

words.def: A summary punitive implement
words.name: Sennet whip

words.def: Navigational instrument used to measure a ship's latitude.
words.name: Sextant

words.def: Section of a ship that houses the propulsion shaft, running from the engine room to the stuffing box.
words.name: Shaft alley

words.def: A cruise performed before a ship enters service or after major changes such as a crew change, repair, or overhaul during which the performance of the ship and her crew are tested under working conditions.
words.name: Shakedown cruise

words.def: Pieces of barrels or casks broken down to save space. They are worth very little, leading to the phrase "no great shakes".
words.name: Shakes

words.def: Condition of a crewman involuntarily impressed into service on a ship.
words.name: Shanghaied

words.def: The upward curve of a vessel's longitudinal lines as viewed from the side.
words.name: Sheer

words.def: In shipbuilding, a diagram showing an elevation of the ship's sheer viewed from the broadside.
words.name: Sheer plan

words.def: A rope used to control the setting of a sail in relation to the direction of the wind.
words.name: Sheet

words.def: An extremely narrow, and often disproportionately long, rowing boat outfitted with long oars, outriggers to hold the oarlocks away from the boat, and sliding seats, specifically designed for racing or exercise.
words.name: Shell (in the United Kingdom also fine boat)

words.def: An upper deck having no overhead protection from the weather itself, but sheltering the deck below it.
words.name: Shelter deck

words.def: Changing the flag and pennant display when a moored vessel becomes underway, and vice versa. A highly coordinated display that ships take pride in; the desired effect is that of one set of flags vanishing while another set flashes out at precisely the same time. Also, slang for changing out of one's Navy uniform into civilian clothes to go ashore. (The U.S. Navy's newsletter for retired personnel is nicknamed Shift Colors from this reason.)[27]
words.name: Shift colors

words.def: Sighting the positions of the sun and moon using a sextant and using a nautical almanac to determine the location and phase of the moon and calculating the relative effect of the tides on the navigation of the ship.[28][29]
words.name: Shift tides

words.def: 1.  Noun – Strictly, a three-masted vessel square-rigged on all three masts, or on three masts of a vessel with more than three. Hence a ship-rigged barque would be a four master, square-rigged on fore, main and mizzen, with spanker and gaff topsail only on the Jigger-mast. Generally now used refers to most medium or large vessels outfitted with smaller boats. As a consequence of this, submarines may be larger than small ships, but are called boats because they do not carry boats of their own.
words.name: Ship

words.def: A type of sailing warship constructed from the 1600s through the mid-1800s to serve as part of the line of battle; the largest and most powerful warships of the era.
words.name: Ship-of-the-line

words.def: Verb – To reenlist. When a sailor extends his or her service another term.
words.name: Ship over

words.def: See full rigged ship.
words.name: Ship-rigged ship

words.def: A type of sloop-of-war introduced in the 1740s which had three square-rigged masts (in contrast to the brig sloop introduced in the 1770s, which had two masts).
words.name: Ship sloop

words.def: Striking the ship's bell is the traditional method of marking time and regulating the crew's watches. Each bell (from one to eight) represents a 30-minute period since the beginning of a four-hour watch. For example, in the classical system, "Three bells in the morning watch" represents 90 minutes since the beginning of the morning watch, or 5:30am. "Eight bells" indicates the end of a watch.
words.name: Ship's bell

words.def: See hard tack.
words.name: Ship's biscuit

words.def: The crew of a ship.
words.name: Ship's company

words.def: The number of persons in a ship's crew, including officers.
words.name: Ship's complement

words.def: Once widely used term, now obsolete, for the man at a dockyard in charge of repairs to a ship. The term derived from the notion that the ship was a "lady" who needed to visit her "husband" when in need of repairs.
words.name: Ship's husband

words.def: A person who designs, builds, and repairs ships, especially wooden ones .
words.name: Shipwright

words.def: A facility where ships or boats are built and repaired. Routinely used as a synonym for dockyard, although dockyard sometimes is associated more closely with a facility used for maintenance and basing activities, while shipyard sometimes is associated more closely with a facility used in construction.
words.name: Shipyard

words.def: Shallow water that is a hazard to navigation.
words.name: Shoal

words.def: Shallow draught, making the vessel capable of sailing in unusually shallow water.
words.name: Shoal draught

words.def: Free time given to officers and crew of a naval vessel when they are off duty and allowed to disembark and spend time on land. See also liberty.
words.name: Shore leave

words.def: The relative slackness of an anchor chain; this term means somewhat slack, but not vertical nor fully extended.
words.name: Short stay

words.def: 1.  To take in the slack of (a rope).
words.name: Shorten

words.def: A shot fired close to and in front of a moving vessel to warn her to stop, often for boarding.
words.name: Shot across the bow

words.def: A rope or cable serving to hold a mast up from side to side.
words.name: Shroud

words.def: Standing rigging running from a mast to the sides of a ships to support the mast sideways. The shrouds work with the stays, which run forward and aft, to support the mast's weight.
words.name: Shrouds

words.def: The compartment reserved for medical purposes.
words.name: Sick bay

words.def: One of an even-numbered group of seamen posted in two rows on the quarterdeck when a visiting dignitary boards or leaves the ship, historically to help (or even hoist) him aboard.
words.name: Sideboy

words.def: 1.  A side-mounted paddle wheel used for propulsion by a paddle steamer.
words.name: Sidewheel

words.def: A sound signal which uses electricity or compressed air to actuate either a disc or a cup shaped rotor.
words.name: Siren

words.def: A ship of the same class as, and therefore virtually identical in design and appearance to, another ship. Sister ships share an identical or nearly identical hull and superstructure layout, similar displacement, and roughly comparable features and equipment. Often, sister ships become more differentiated during their service lives as their equipment (and, in the case of military ships, their armament) are separately altered.
words.name: Sister ship

words.def: A downward or sternward projection from the keel in front of the rudder. Protects the rudder from damage, and in bilge keelers may provide one "leg" of a tripod on which the boat stands when the tide is out.
words.name: Skeg

words.def: A small boat, traditionally a coastal or river craft, for leisure or fishing, with a single person or small crew. Sailing skiffs have developed into high performance competitive classes.
words.name: Skiff

words.def: The captain of a ship.
words.name: Skipper

words.def: A sail set very high, above the royals. Only carried by a few ships.
words.name: Skysail

words.def: A small, triangular sail, above the skysail. Used in light winds on a few ships.
words.name: Skyscraper

words.def: That period between rising tide and falling tide. or that period between falling tide and rising tide when there is no tidal induced current.
words.name: Slack tide

words.def: 1.  To pass a rope around something preparatory to attaching a hoisting or lowering tackle to it.
words.name: Sling

words.def: 1.  A berth for a ship or boat; a place for a ship or boat to moor.
words.name: Slip

words.def: A ramp on the shore by which ships or boats can be moved to and from the water. Slipways are used for building and repairing ships and boats. They are also used for launching and retrieving small boats on trailers towed by automobiles and flying boats on their undercarriage.
words.name: Slipway

words.def: A small to mid-sized sailboat larger than a dinghy, with one mast bearing a main sail and head sail and located farther forward than the mast of a cutter.
words.name: Sloop

words.def: 1.  In the 18th and 19th centuries, a small sailing warship carrying 18 or fewer guns with a single continuous gundeck.
words.name: Sloop-of-war

words.def: A ship's store of merchandise, such as clothing, tobacco, etc., maintained aboard merchant ships for sale to the crew.
words.name: Slop chest

words.def: Greasy substance obtained by boiling or scraping the fat from empty salted meat storage barrels, or the floating fat residue after boiling the crew's meal. In the Royal Navy the perquisite of the cook who could sell it or exchange it (usually for alcohol) with other members of the crew. Used for greasing parts of the running rigging of the ship and therefore valuable to the master and bosun.
words.name: Slush

words.def: The money obtained by the cook selling slush ashore. Used for the benefit of the crew (or the cook).
words.name: Slush fund

words.def: A traditional fishing boat used off the coast of England and the Atlantic coast of America for most of the 19th century and in small numbers up to the mid-20th century. Originally a cutter-rigged sailing boat, after about 1865 lengthened and given a ketch rig. Some had a topsail on the mizzen mast, others a bowsprit carrying a jib.
words.name: Smack

words.def: The smaller of two anchors carried in the bow.
words.name: Small bower (anchor)

words.def: A midshipman (Royal Navy slang.)[30]
words.name: Snotty

words.def: A form of brig where the gaff spanker or driver is rigged on a "snow mast" a lighter spar supported in chocks close behind the main-mast.
words.name: Snow

words.def: Template:Defnl1= An eye splice without a thimble fitted.
words.name: Soft Eye

words.def: Speed over ground, speed of the vessel relative to the Earth (and as shown by a GPS). Referenced on many fishing forums.
words.name: SOG

words.def: 1.  An acronym for SOund Navigation And Ranging, a method of using sound pulses to detect, range, and sometimes image underwater targets and obstacles or the bed of the sea. See also echo sounding and ASDIC.
words.name: Sonar

words.def:
Sounding.


Measuring the depth of the water. Traditionally done by swinging the lead, now commonly by echo sounding.
words.name: Sounding

words.def: 1.  A storm from the south west.
words.name: Sou'wester

words.def: A fore-and-aft or gaff-rigged sail on the aft-most mast of a square-rigged vessel and the main fore-and-aft sail (spanker sail) on the aft-most mast of a (partially) fore-and-aft rigged vessel such as a schooner, a barquentine, and a barque.
words.name: Spanker

words.def: The aft-most mast of a fore-and-aft or gaff-rigged vessel such as schooners, barquentines, and barques. A full-rigged ship has a spanker sail but not a spanker-mast (see Jigger-mast).
words.name: Spanker-mast

words.def: A wooden, in later years also iron or steel pole used to support various pieces of rigging and sails. The big five-masted full-rigged tall ship Preussen (German spelling: Preußen) had crossed 30 steel yards, but only one wooden spar—the little gaff of its spanker sail.
words.name: Spar

words.def: A weapon consisting of a bomb placed at the end of a long spar and attached to a boat.
words.name: Spar torpedo

words.def: see communication tube.
words.name: Speaking tube

words.def: An iron band around the base of a mast which holds a set of iron belaying pins.
words.name: Spider band or Spider hoop

words.def: Finely divided water swept from crest of waves by strong winds.
words.name: Spindrift

words.def: A large sail flown in front of the vessel while heading downwind.
words.name: Spinnaker

words.def: A spar used to help control a spinnaker or other headsail.
words.name: Spinnaker pole

words.def: A projection from the side of a vessel for protection, stability, or the mounting of equipment such as armaments or lifeboats. A sponson that extends a hull dimension at or below the waterline serves to increase flotation or add lift when underway.
words.name: Sponson

words.def: The person, traditionally a woman, who christens a ship at its launching ceremony.
words.name: Sponsor

words.def: A platform on a mast used to aid in gun laying.
words.name: Spotting top

words.def: A line used parallel to that of the length of a craft, to prevent fore-aft motion of a boat, when moored or docked.
words.name: Spring

words.def: To join lines (ropes, cables, etc.) by unravelling their ends and intertwining them to form a continuous line. To form an eye or a knot by splicing.
words.name: Splice

words.def: A euphemism, it is an order given aboard naval vessels to issue the crew with a drink, traditionally grog. The phrase splice the mainbrace is used idiomatically meaning to go ashore on liberty, intending to go out for an evening of drinking.
words.name: Splice the mainbrace

words.def: A spar on a sailboat used to deflect the shrouds to allow them to better support the mast.
words.name: Spreader

words.def: A pipe that connects to the chain locker, from which the anchor chain emerges onto the deck at the bow of a ship.
words.name: Spurling pipe

words.def: 1.  In general, any significant group of warships which is considered too small to be designated a fleet, but otherwise not strictly defined by size. In some navies, the term flotilla may be used instead of or in addition to "squadron" to describe a significant group of warships smaller than a fleet.
words.name: Squadron

words.def: To place at right angles with the mast or keel and parallel to the horizon e.g., "to square the yards."
words.name: Square

words.def: A sufficient quantity of food. Meals on board ship were served to the crew on a square wooden plate in harbor or at sea in good weather. Food in the Royal Navy was invariably better or at least in greater quantity than that available to the average landsman. However, while square wooden plates were indeed used on board ship, there is no established link between them and this particular term. The OED gives the earliest reference from the U.S. in the mid-19th century.
words.name: Square meal

words.def: A generic type of sail and rigging arrangement in which the primary driving sails are carried on yards which are perpendicular, or square, to the keel of the vessel and to the masts. A ship mainly so rigged is said to be square-rigged.
words.name: Square rig

words.def: A ship which is square-rigged.
words.name: Square rigger

words.def: Yards held rigidly perpendicular to their masts and parallel to the deck. This was rarely the best trim of the yards for efficiency but made a pretty sight for inspections and in harbor. The term is applied to situations and to people figuratively to mean that all difficulties have been resolved or that the person is performing well and is mentally and physically prepared.
words.name: Squared away

words.def: The phenomenon by which a vessel moving quickly through shallow water creates an area of lowered pressure under its keel that reduces the ship's buoyancy, particularly at the bow. The reduced buoyancy causes the ship to "squat" lower in the water than would ordinarily be expected, and thus its effective draught is increased.
words.name: Squat effect

words.def: Prefix for "Steam Ship", used before a ship's name.
words.name: S.S. (or SS)

words.def: See funnel.
words.name: Stack (also funnel)

words.def: vertical post near a deck's edge that supports life-lines. A timber fitted in between the frame heads on a wooden hull or a bracket on a steel vessel, approx one meter high, to support the bulwark plank or plating and the rail.
words.name: Stanchion

words.def: Of a ship or its captain, to steer, sail, or steam, usually used in conjunction with a specified direction or destination, e.g., The ship stood out of the harbor or The ship stood toward the east or The ship stood toward the missing vessel's last known position.
words.name: Stand (past tense stood)

words.def: A vessel directed to keep her course and speed where two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve a risk of collision.
words.name: Stand-on (vessel)

words.def: Rigging which is used to support masts and spars, and is not normally manipulated during normal operations. Cf. running rigging.
words.name: Standing rigging

words.def: The right side of the boat. Towards the right-hand side of a vessel facing forward. Denoted with a green light at night. Derived from the old steering oar or steerboard which preceded the invention of the rudder.
words.name: Starboard

words.def: When sailing with the wind coming from the starboard side of the vessel. Has right of way over boats on port tack.
words.name: Starboard tack

words.def: A rope used as a punitive device. See teazer, togey.
words.name: Starter

words.def: 1.  A superior cabin for a vessel's officer.
words.name: Stateroom

words.def: 1.  In chiefly 19th- and early 20th-century usage, a naval formation under a commander-in-chief who controls all naval operations, and sometimes all naval shore facilities, within a specified geographic area (e.g., the China Station, the East Indies Station, etc.), sometimes synonymous with squadron (q.v.).
words.name: Station

words.def: 1.  A strong rope supporting a mast, and leading from the head of one mast down to some other mast or other part of the vessel; rigging running fore (forestay) and aft (backstay) from a mast to the hull. The stays support a mast's weight forward and aft, while the shrouds support its weight from side to side.
words.name: Stay

words.def: A sail whose luff is attached to a forestay.
words.name: Staysail

words.def: A vessel equipped with steam propulsion. Also steamboat or steamship.
words.name: Steamer

words.def: 1.  The effect of the helm on a vessel; the act of steering a vessel.
words.name: Steerage

words.def: The minimum speed at which a vessel will answer the helm, below which she cannot be steered. Speed sufficient for the rudder to "bite."
words.name: Steerageway

words.def: In a vessel, the compartment containing the steering gear.
words.name: Steering flat

words.def: A long, flat board or oar that went from the stern to well underwater, used to steer vessels before the invention of the rudder. Traditionally on the starboard side of a ship (the "steering board" side).
words.name: Steering oar or steering board

words.def: 1.  A spar or derrick with a block at one end, used for stowing cargo.
words.name: Steeve

words.def: The extension of keel at the forward end of a ship.
words.name: Stem

words.def: The rear part of a ship, technically defined as the area built up over the sternpost, extending upwards from the counter rail to the taffrail.
words.name: Stern

words.def: See chase gun.
words.name: Stern chaser

words.def: 1.  The tube under the hull to bear the tailshaft for propulsion (usually at stern).
words.name: Stern tube

words.def: A propeller drive system similar to the lower part of an outboard motor extending below the hull of a larger power boat or yacht, but driven by an engine mounted within the hull. Unlike a fixed propeller (but like an outboard), the boat may be steered by twisting the drive. See also inboard motor and outboard motor.
words.name: Sterndrive

words.def: An external walkway or gallery for the use of officers installed on the stern chiefly of British warships until the early 20th century.
words.name: Sternwalk

words.def: The reverse movement of a boat or watercraft through the water.
words.name: Sternway

words.def: A member of a vessel's crew involved in commissary duties or in personal services to passengers or other crew members.
words.name: Steward

words.def: See Stand.
words.name: Stood

words.def: (also "store ship" or "stores ship")
words.name: Storeship

words.def: (archaic) A continuous line of plates or planks running from bow to stern that contributes to a vessel's skin. The planks or plates next to the keel are called the garboard strakes; the next, or the heavy strakes at the bilge, are the bilge strakes; the next, from the water line to the lower port sill, the wales; and the upper parts of the sides, the sheer strakes.
words.name: Strake

words.def: 1.  To haul down or lower (a flag, mast, etc.).
words.name: Strike

words.def: To surrender the vessel to an enemy, from the custom during the Age of Sail of lowering the vessel's ensign to indicate that she is surrendering.
words.name: Strike the colors

words.def: A knot tied in the end of a rope, usually to stop it passing through a hole; most commonly a figure-eight knot.
words.name: Stopper knot

words.def: (past tense of stave, often applied as present tense) to smash inward, to force a hole or break in, as in a cask, door or other (wooden) barrier.
words.name: Stove or Stove in

words.def: to store, or to put away e.g. personal effects, tackle, or cargo.
words.name: Stow

words.def: the amount of room for storing materials on board a ship.
words.name: Stowage

words.def: A trespasser on a ship; a person aboard a ship without permission and/or without payment, and usually boards undetected, remains hidden aboard, and jumps ship just before making port or reaching a port's dock; sometimes found aboard and imprisoned in the brig until the ship makes port and the prisoner can be transferred to the police or military.
words.name: Stowaway

words.def: In a convoy, a ship that is unable to maintain speed and falls behind.
words.name: Straggler

words.def: One of the overlapping boards in a clinker built hull.
words.name: Strake

words.def: an inclined foot rest, attached to the boat, to which a rower may place and in some instances (usually in competition) attach his feet.
words.name: Stretcher

words.def: Long and narrow sails, used only in fine weather, on the outside of the large square sails.
words.name: Studding sails /ˈstʌnsəl/

words.def: Speed through (the) water, speed of the vessel relative to the surrounding water (and as shown by a Log). Used in navigation.
words.name: STW

words.def: A personal-sized, beach-launched sailing dinghy with a pontoon-type hull, daggerboard, and lateen sail mounted to an un-stayed mast.
words.name: Sunfish

words.def: The parts of the ship or a boat, including sailboats, fishing boats, passenger ships, and submarines, that project above her main deck. This does not usually include its masts or any armament turrets.
words.name: Superstructure

words.def: A vessel's transient motion in a fore and aft direction.
words.name: Surge

words.def: Any type of ship or boat that is used for mapping a body of water's bottom, benthic zone, full water column, and surface for purposes of hydrography, general oceanography, marine salvage, dredging, marine archaeology, or the study of marine habitats.
words.name: Survey vessel

words.def: 1.  A vessel's lateral motion from side to side.
words.name: Sway

words.def: A long oar used to steer an unpowered lighter.
words.name: Sweep

words.def: To take up the last bit of slack on a line such as a halyard, anchor line or dockline by taking a single turn round a cleat and alternately heaving on the rope above and below the cleat while keeping the tension on the tail.
words.name: Swigging

words.def: Measuring the accuracy in a ship's magnetic compass so its readings can be adjusted—often by turning the ship and taking bearings on reference points.
words.name: Swinging the compass

words.def: Telling sea stories. Referring to lamps slung from the deckhead which swing while at sea. Often used to indicate that the story teller is exaggerating.
words.name: Swinging the lamp

words.def: 1.  Measuring the depth of water beneath a ship using a lead-weighted sounding line. Regarded as a relatively easy job, thus:
words.name: Swinging the lead

words.def: A large bracket attached firmly to the deck, to which the foot of the mast is fixed. It has two sides or cheeks and a bolt forming the pivot around which the mast is raised and lowered.
words.name: Tabernacle

words.def: 1.  A leg of the route of a sailing vessel, particularly in relation to tacking (q.v.) and to starboard tack and port tack (also q.v.).
words.name: Tack

words.def: 1.  Zig-zagging so as to sail directly towards the wind (and for some rigs also away from it).
words.name: Tacking

words.def: In sailboat racing on an upwind leg of the race course the complex maneuvers of lead and overtaking boats to vie for the aerodynamic advantage of clear air. This results from the ongoing strategy of the lead boat's effort to keep the following boat(s) in the blanket of disturbed bad air he is creating.
words.name: Tacking duels

words.def: The perpendicular distance between a ship's course when the helm is put hard over and her course when she has turned through 180 degrees; the ratio of the tactical diameter divided by the ship's length between perpendiculars gives a dimensionless parameter which can be used to compare the maneuverability of ships.
words.name: Tactical diameter

words.def: A rail at the stern of the boat that covers the head of the counter timbers.
words.name: Taffrail

words.def: A kind of metallic shafting (a rod of metal) to hold the propeller and connected to the power engine. When the tailshaft is moved, the propeller may also be moved for propulsion.
words.name: Tailshaft

words.def: An inattentive helmsmen might allow the dangerous situation to arise where the wind is blowing into the sails 'backwards', causing a sudden (and possibly dangerous) shift in the position of the sails.
words.name: Taken aback

words.def: To sail in a way that steals the wind from another ship. cf. overbear.
words.name: Taking the wind out of his sails

words.def: The operation of hauling aft the sheets, or drawing them in the direction of the ship's stern.
words.name: Tally

words.def: A ship designed to transport liquids in bulk.
words.name: Tanker (also tank ship or tankship)

words.def: A vessel, typically an obsolete or captured warship, used for naval gunnery practice or for weapons testing. The term includes both ships intended to be sunk and ships intended to survive and see repeated use as a target.
words.name: Target ship

words.def: Temporary naval organisations composed of particular ships, aircraft, submarines, military land forces, or shore service units, assigned to fulfill certain missions. Seemingly drawn originally from Royal Navy heritage, the emphasis is placed on the individual commander of the unit, and references to 'CTF' are common for "Commander Task Force".
words.name: Task Force

words.def: Light cord attached to a mooring line at two points a few inches apart with a slack section in between (resembling an inch-worm) to indicate when the line is stretching from the ship's rising with the tide. Obviously only used when moored to a fixed dock or pier and only on watches with a flood tide.
words.name: Tattle Tale

words.def: A light piece of string, yarn, rope or plastic (often magnetic audio tape) attached to a stay or a shroud to indicate the local wind direction. They may also be attached to the surface and/or the leech of a sail to indicate the state of the air flow over the surface of the sail. They are referenced when optimizing the trim of the sails to achieve the best boat speed in the prevailing wind conditions. (See dogvane)
words.name: Tell-tale (sometimes tell-tail)

words.def: 1.  A type of naval auxiliary ship (q.v.) designed to provide advanced basing services in undeveloped harbors to seaplanes, flying boats, torpedo boats, destroyers, or submarines.
words.name: Tender

words.def: Prefix for "Turbo-Electric Vessel," used before a ship's name.
words.name: T.E.V. (or TEV)

words.def: Also called the third officer, a licensed member of the deck department of a merchant ship, fourth – or on some ocean liners fifth – in command; a watchkeeping officer, customarily also the ship's safety officer, responsible for the ship's firefighting equipment, lifeboats, and other emergency systems. Other duties of the third mate vary depending on the type of ship, its crewing, and other factors.
words.name: Third mate

words.def: See third mate.
words.name: Third officer

words.def: Vertical wooden peg or pin inserted through the gunwale to form a fulcrum for oars when rowing. Used in place of a rowlock.
words.name: Thole

words.def: On a three-masted ship, having the sheets of the three lower courses loose will result in the ship meandering aimlessly downwind. Also, a sailor who has drunk strong spirits beyond his capacity.
words.name: Three sheets to the wind

words.def: A bench seat across the width of an open boat.
words.name: Thwart /ˈθwɔːrt/

words.def: From the French timonnier, is a name given, on particular occasions, to the steersman of a ship.
words.name: Timoneer

words.def: U.S. Navy slang for a destroyer; often shortened to can (q.v.).
words.name: Tin can

words.def: A lightly armored steam-powered river gunboat used by the United States Navy during the American Civil War (1861–1865).
words.name: Tinclad

words.def: A thin temporary patch.
words.name: Tingle

words.def: a lever used for steering, attached to the top of the rudder post. Used mainly on smaller vessels, such as dinghies and rowing boats.
words.name: Tiller

words.def: A low strip running around the edge of the deck like a low bulwark. It may be shortened or have gaps in it to allow water to flow off the deck.
words.name: Toe-rail

words.def: At parade, sailors and soldiers were required to stand in line, their toes in line with a seam of the deck.
words.name: Toe the line or Toe the mark

words.def: A block of wood inserted into the barrel of a gun on a 19th-century warship to keep out the sea spray; also used for covers for the ends of the barrels of more modern ships' guns, the larger of which are often adorned with the ship's crest or other decoration.
words.name: Tompion

words.def:
Various measures of the size or cargo carrying capacity of a ship, including:
1. Deadweight tonnage, the total weight of a vessel, mostly without payload.
words.name: Tonnage

words.def: The platform at the upper end of each (lower) mast of a square-rigged ship, typically one-fourth to one-third of the way up the mast. The main purpose of a top is to anchor the shrouds of the topmast that extends above it. See also fighting top.
words.name: Top

words.def: The mast or sails above the tops. (See topgallant mast and topgallant sail.)
words.name: Topgallant

words.def: A collective term for the masts, yards, sails and rigging of a sailing ship, or for similarly insubstantial structures above the upper deck of any ship.[32]
words.name: Tophamper

words.def: A crewmember stationed in a top.
words.name: Topman

words.def: The second section of the mast above the deck; formerly the upper mast, later surmounted by the topgallant mast; carrying the topsails.
words.name: Topmast

words.def: a line which is part of the rigging on a sailing boat; it applies upward force on a spar or boom. The most common topping lift on a modern sailing boat is attached to the boom
words.name: Topping lift

words.def: The second sail (counting from the bottom) up a mast. These may be either square sails or fore-and-aft ones, in which case they often "fill in" between the mast and the gaff of the sail below.
words.name: Topsail

words.def: the part of the hull between the waterline and the deck. Also, Above-water hull
words.name: Topsides

words.def: 1.  Prior to about 1900, the term for a variety of explosive devices designed for use in water, including mines, spar torpedoes and, after the mid-19th century, "automotive," "automobile," "locomotive," or "fish" torpedoes (self-propelled weapons which fit the modern definition of "torpedo").
words.name: Torpedo

words.def: 1.  The bottom of the ship touching the bottom, but not grounding.
words.name: Touch and go

words.def: The operation of drawing a vessel forward by means of long lines.
words.name: Towing

words.def: Shipping corridors marked by buoys which separate incoming from outgoing vessels. Improperly called Sea Lanes.
words.name: Traffic Separation Scheme

words.def: A decorative board at the bow of a vessel, sometimes bearing the vessel's name.
words.name: Trailboard

words.def: A ship used to train students as sailors, especially a ship employed by a navy or coast guard to train future officers. The term refers both to ships used for training at sea and to old, immobile hulks used to house classrooms.
words.name: Training ship

words.def: A cargo ship engaged in the tramp trade.
words.name: Tramp freighter

words.def: A steamship engaged in the tramp trade.
words.name: Tramp steamer

words.def: Shipping trade on the spot market in which the vessels involved do not have a fixed schedule or itinerary or published ports of call. This contrasts with freight liner service, in which vessels make regular, scheduled runs between published ports.
words.name: Tramp trade

words.def: A vessel engaged in the tramp trade.
words.name: Tramper

words.def: British term for a room located in the interior of a ship containing computers and other specialised equipment needed to calculate the range and bearing of a target from information gathered by the ship's spotters and range finders. These were designated "plotting rooms" by the United States Navy.[33]
words.name: Transmitting station

words.def: The aft "wall" of the stern; often the part to which an outboard unit or the drive portion of a sterndrive is attached. A more or less flat surface across the stern of a vessel. Dinghies tend to have almost vertical transoms, whereas yachts' transoms may be raked forward or aft.
words.name: Transom

words.def: See troopship.
words.name: Transport

words.def: Small fittings that slide on a rod or line. The most common use is for the inboard end of the mainsheet; a more esoteric form of traveller consists of "slight iron rings, encircling the backstays, which are used for hoisting the top-gallant yards, and confining them to the backstays".
words.name: Travellers

words.def: 1.  Commercial trawler, a fishing boat that uses a trawl net or dragnet to catch fish.
words.name: Trawler

words.def: A wooden peg, pin, or dowel used to fasten pieces of wood together, particularly the hull, gunnels, thwarts, etc.
words.name: Treenail (also trenail, trennel, or trunnel)

words.def: To haul and tie up by means of a rope.
words.name: Trice

words.def: A period of time spent at the wheel ("my trick's over").
words.name: Trick

words.def: 1.  Relationship of ship's hull to waterline.
words.name: Trim

words.def: A vessel with three hulls.
words.name: Trimaran

words.def: person responsible for ensuring that a vessel remains in 'trim' (that the cargo and fuel are evenly balanced). An important task on a coal-fired vessel, as it could get 'out-of-trim' coal is consumed.
words.name: Trimmer, sometimes Coal trimmer

words.def: Operating as a troopship.
words.name: Trooping

words.def: A ship used to carry soldiers. Troopships are not specially designed for military operations and unlike landing ships cannot land troops directly onto a shore; instead they unload troops at a harbor or onto smaller vessels for transportation to shore.
words.name: Troopship (also troop ship, troop transport, or trooper)

words.def: An absolute bearing (q.v.) using true north.
words.name: True bearing

words.def: The direction of the geographical North Pole.
words.name: True north

words.def: The rope or iron used to keep the center of a yard to the mast.
words.name: Truss

words.def: A boat that maneuvers other vessels by pushing or towing them. Tugs are powerful for their size and strongly built, and some are ocean-going.
words.name: Tug or tugboat

words.def: Hull shape, when viewed in a transverse section, where the widest part of the hull is someway below deck level.
words.name: Tumblehome

words.def: A knot passing behind or around an object.
words.name: Turn

words.def: A term meaning "Get to work," often hand-signed by two fingers and hand motion in turning fashion.
words.name: Turn To (Turn Two)

words.def: see bottlescrew.
words.name: Turnbuckle

words.def: 1.  Originally (in the mid-to-late 19th century), an enclosed armored rotating cylindrical box mounting guns which fired through gunports, the turret rotating over a bearing mounted on a ship's deck or within her hull. Turret-equipped ships contrasted sharply with those equipped with barbettes, which in the second half of the 19th century were open-topped armored rings over which rotating gun(s) mounted on a turntable could fire.
words.name: Turret

words.def: A deck that has slight positive curvature when viewed in cross-section. The purpose of this curvature is usually to shed water, but in warships it also functions to make the deck more resistant to shells.
words.name: Turtleback deck

words.def: In dinghy sailing especially (but can include other boats), a boat is said to be turtling or to turn turtle when the boat is fully inverted with the mast pointing down to the lake bottom or seabed.[A] [35][36]
words.name: Turtling

words.def: A deck on a general cargo ship located between the main deck (or weather deck) and the hold space. A general cargo ship may have one or two tweendecks (or none at all).
words.name: Tweendeck

words.def: The space on a tweendeck available for carrying cargo or other uses.
words.name: Tweendeck space

words.def: A general cargo ship equipped with one or more tweendecks.
words.name: Tweendecker

words.def: Royal Navy slang term meaning to pull. Originally a sailing navy term referring to the two members of a gun crew (numbers two and six) who ran out the gun by pulling on the ropes that secured it in place.
words.name: Two six heave

words.def: A chain or rope used for hoisting or lowering a yard. A tye runs from the horizontal center of a given yard to a corresponding mast and from there down to a tackle. Sometimes specifically called a chain tye or a rope tye.
words.name: Tye

words.def: A voyage, usually singlehanded, with no intermediate port stops or physical assistance from external sources.
words.name: Unassisted sailing

words.def: Serving a watch on the weather side of the ship, exposed to wind and spray.
words.name: Under the weather

words.def: A vessel that is moving under control: that is, neither at anchor, made fast to the shore, aground nor adrift. Way refers to speed sufficient to steer with the rudder. "Under weigh" is an erroneous synonym.
words.name: Under way or underway

words.def: The underwater section of a vessel beneath the waterline, normally not visible except when in drydock or (historically), careened.
words.name: Underwater hull or underwater ship

words.def: A method employed by navies to transfer fuel, munitions, and stores from one ship to another while underway. Sometimes abbreviation as UNREP.
words.name: Underway replenishment

words.def: 1.  To remove from a vessel.
words.name: Unship

words.def: The relative slackness of an anchor chain where the anchor chain is slack and hangs vertically down from the hawsepipe.
words.name: Up-and-down

words.def: Slack off quickly and run slack to a belaying point. This order is given when a line or wire has been stopped off or falls have been four-in-hand and the hauling part is to be belayed.
words.name: Up-behind

words.def: 1.  A vessel traveling upstream.
words.name: Upbound

words.def: Specially selected personnel destined for high office.
words.name: Upper-yardmen

words.def: The shape of a boat or ship in which the contours of the hull come in a straight line to the keel.
words.name: V-hull

words.def: 1.  A rope (line) leading from gaff to either side of the deck, used to prevent the gaff from sagging.
words.name: Vang

words.def: The maximum degree of heel after which a vessel becomes unable to return to an upright position.
words.name: Vanishing angle

words.def: Any craft designed for transportation on water, such as a ship or boat.
words.name: Vessel

words.def: see communication tube.
words.name: Voice pipe or voice tube

words.def: 1.  A long journey by ship.
words.name: Voyage

words.def: A signal flag on a vessel.
words.name: Waft

words.def: the central deck of a ship between the forecastle and the quarterdeck.[37]
words.name: Waist

words.def: Turbulence behind a vessel. Not to be confused with wash.
words.name: Wake

words.def: Any of the strong and thick planks running lengthwise along a vessel, forming the lower part of the vessel's sides.
words.name: Wale

words.def: 1.  The living quarters of a naval ship designated for the use of commissioned officers other than the captain.
words.name: Wardroom

words.def: 1.  To move a vessel by hauling on a line or cable that is fastened to an anchor or pier; especially to move a sailing ship through a restricted place such as a harbor.
words.name: Warp

words.def: The waves created by a vessel. Not to be confused with wake.
words.name: Wash

words.def: A period of time during which a part of the crew is on duty. Changes of watch are marked by strokes on the ship's bell.
words.name: Watch

words.def: The allocation of crew or staff to a Watch
words.name: Watchstanding

words.def: Water transport vessels. Ships, boats, personal water craft, etc.
words.name: Watercraft

words.def: The line where the hull of a ship meets the water's surface.
words.name: Waterline

words.def: A sail hung below the boom on gaff rig boats for extra downwind performance when racing.
words.name: Watersail

words.def: 1.  Waterway, a navigable body of water.
words.name: Waterway

words.def: Speed, progress, or momentum, or more technically, the point at which there is sufficient water flow past a vessel's rudder for it to be able to steer the vessel (i.e., the rudder begins to "bite," sometimes also called "steerage way.") To make way is to move; to "have way on" or "to have steerage way" is to have enough speed to control the vessel with its rudder; to lose way is to slow down or to not have enough speed to control with the rudder. "Way enough" is a coxswain's command that the oarsmen stop rowing, and allow the boat to proceed with its existing way.
words.name: Way

words.def: An intermediate stop along the route of a steamboat.
words.name: Way-landing

words.def: A location defined by navigational coordinates, especially as part of a planned route.
words.name: Waypoint

words.def: The timbers of shipyard stocks that slope into the water and along which a ship or large boat is launched. A ship undergoing construction in a shipyard is said to be on the ways, while a ship scrapped there is said to be broken up in the ways.
words.name: Ways

words.def: Tacking away from the wind in a square-rigged vessel. See also gybe.
words.name: Wearing ship

words.def: Whichever deck is that exposed to the weather—usually either the main deck or, in larger vessels, the upper deck.
words.name: Weather deck

words.def: Favorable position over another sailing vessel with respect to the wind.
words.name: Weather gage or weather gauge or weather-beam

words.def: The tendency of a sailboat to turn to windward in a strong wind when there is no change in the rudder's position. This is the opposite of lee helm and is the result of a dynamically unbalanced condition. See also Center of lateral resistance.
words.name: Weather helm

words.def: A ship stationed in the ocean as a platform for surface and upper air meteorological observations for use in weather forecasting.
words.name: Weather ship

words.def: The side of a ship exposed to the wind.
words.name: Weather side

words.def: A ship that is easily sailed and maneuvered; makes little leeway when sailing to windward.
words.name: Weatherly

words.def: To heave up (an anchor) preparatory to sailing.
words.name: Weigh anchor

words.def: Place in the ship's hold for pumps.
words.name: Well

words.def: Properly set up or provisioned.
words.name: Well-found

words.def: In sailboating, portion of the hull immersed in water.
words.name: Wetted area

words.def: 1.  A type of open boat that is relatively narrow and pointed at both ends, enabling it to move either forwards or backwards equally well.
words.name: Whaleboat

words.def: 1.  A specialized vessel designed for catching or processing whales.
words.name: Whaler

words.def: A structure on the shore of a harbor or on the bank of a river or canal where ships may dock to load and unload cargo or passengers. Such a structure includes one or more berths (i.e., mooring locations), and may also include piers, warehouses, or other facilities necessary for handling the ships. The term "wharf' is generally synonymous with "quay" (q.v.), although the solid foundations of a quay contrast with the closely spaced piles of a wharf. When "quay" and "wharf" are used as synonyms, the term "quay" is more common in everyday speech in the United Kingdom, many Commonwealth countries, and the Republic of Ireland, while "wharf" is more commonly used in the United States.
words.name: Wharf

words.def: The usual steering device on larger vessels: a wheel with a horizontal axis, connected by cables to the rudder.
words.name: Wheel or ship's wheel

words.def: Location on a ship where the wheel is located; also called pilothouse or bridge.
words.name: Wheelhouse

words.def: A small sailing pram.
words.name: Whelkie

words.def: A type of boat traditionally used for carrying cargo or passengers on rivers and canals in England, particularly on the River Thames and the Norfolk and Suffolk Broads.
words.name: Wherry

words.def: A chiefly British term for a narrow clinker-built skiff having outriggers, for one oarsman.
words.name: Whiff

words.def: Spreaders from the bows to spread the bowsprit shrouds.
words.name: Whiskers

words.def: One of the pair of stays that stabilize the bowsprit horizontally affixed to forward end of the bowsprit and just aft the stem.
words.name: Whiskerstay

words.def: Foam or spray on wave tops caused by stronger winds (usually above Force 4).
words.name: White horses or whitecaps

words.def: To leave room between two ships moored (berthed) to allow space for maneuver.
words.name: Wide berth

words.def: A vertical lever connected to a tiller, used for steering on larger ships before the development of the ship's wheel.
words.name: Whipstaff

words.def: Sea conditions with a tidal current and a wind in opposite directions, leading to short, heavy seas.
words.name: Wind-over-tide

words.def: Wind resistance of the boat.
words.name: Windage

words.def: A condition wherein the ship is detained in one particular station by contrary winds.
words.name: Windbound

words.def: A large iron- or steel-hulled square-rigged sailing ship of the late 19th and early 20th centuries with three, four, or five masts , built mainly between the 1870s and 1900 to carry cargo on long voyages.
words.name: Windjammer

words.def: A winch mechanism, usually with a horizontal axis. Used where mechanical advantage greater than that obtainable by block and tackle was needed (such as raising the anchor on small ships).
words.name: Windlass

words.def: A wide tube or funnel of canvas, used to convey a stream of air into the lower compartments of a ship for ventilation.
words.name: Windsail

words.def: In the direction that the wind is coming from.
words.name: Windward

words.def: An extension on the side of a vessel. A bridge wing is an open-air extension of the bridge to port or starboard, intended for use in signaling.
words.name: Wing

words.def: Training, usually including gunnery practice.
words.name: Working up

words.def: To protect a section of rope from chafing by: laying yarns (worming) to fill in the cuntlines, wrapping marline or other small stuff (serving) around it, and stitching a covering of canvas (parceling) over all.
words.name: Worm, parcel and serve

words.def: A recreational boat or ship; the term includes sailing yachts, motor yachts, and steam yachts.
words.name: Yacht

words.def: 1.  Yard: The horizontal spar from which a square sail is suspended.
words.name: Yard

words.def: Each shipyard typically numbers the ships that it has built in consecutive order. One use is to identify the ship before a name has been chosen.
words.name: Yard number

words.def: The very end of a yard. Often mistaken for a "yard", which refers to the entire spar. As in to hang "from the yardarm" and the sun being "over the yardarm" (late enough to have a drink).
words.name: Yardarm

words.def: Acknowledgement of an order, or agreement. Also aye, aye.
words.name: Yarr

words.def: A vessel's rotational motion about the vertical axis, causing the fore and aft ends to swing from side to side repetitively.
words.name: Yaw

words.def: A fore-and-aft rigged sailing vessel with two masts, main and mizzen, the mizzen stepped abaft the rudder post.
words.name: Yawl

words.def: A rowboat on davits at the stern of the boat.
words.name: Yawl boat
